SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; HABITATS/Crow Hill, Crown Heights; Pg. 4

HEADLINE: It Grows in Brooklyn: It's Not a Tree, but It's Green

BYLINE: By PENELOPE GREEN

 BODY:
FOR nearly a year, they owned a full city block in Brooklyn: 135,000 square feet in seven buildings on three tax lots from Franklin Avenue to the elevated Franklin Avenue Shuttle, and from Dean to Bergen Streets. It's an awkwardly beautiful landscape of steel and brick, concrete and cobblestone; a one-story garage is topped by a large, lovely rusted hopper, and other buildings line up at different heights, like jagged teeth in a hobo's mouth. Even the el is poetic, a rough river melody rolling through masonry pastures. 
 Still, Susan Boyle and Benton Brown did not aspire to such vast holdings. Ms. Boyle, who is 31 and has a degree in environmental studies and economics, and Mr. Brown, also 31 and a sculptor with degrees in fine arts and political science, had an idea about renovating an abandoned building into a live-work space, using green technologies and their own sweat equity. A small building, that is, with maybe a little extra space for one tenant. Their renovation has wound up being considerably larger, though not 135,000 square feet. 
 Mr. Brown had already domesticated a loft near the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and as the son of an architect was pretty sanguine about construction. Ms. Boyle was working for Transportation Alternatives, a citizens' group working for better public transit, and was eager to investigate green building practices and sustainable energy sources. 
 But after a year of chasing properties throughout Brooklyn -- one step behind the developers, or a bid too low in the case of a carriage house they loved and lost -- they found themselves facing an elegant, though pigeon-infested, former ice house that, at 14,000 square feet, was somewhat bigger than their idea of home sweet home. And, as comely as it was, its owner, the principal of a moving and storage company, would not detach it in sale from the melange of 19th- and 20th-century structures that crowded about it and stretched away from the el.
 The owner was a nice guy, though, and a trusting one. He allowed them to list for sale all the properties except their ice house and its companion, a 46,000-square-foot brick building on Bergen Street, as they went into contract in 2001. Within 11 months, the other properties were sold to Artopolis, a nonprofit arts organization, and the Community Preservation Corporation, a private mortgage lender of low- to middle-income housing, for nearly the same amount -- about $2.3 million -- as they had paid for the full city block. (Artopolis will develop its new property into 67 artists' co-ops, which will list for about $25 a square foot when they are finished next year, said David Judelson, a director of Artopolis.) 
 This new compound makes a happy addition to Crow Hill, in the northern end of Crown Heights. For seven years, the area has been shaking off decades of neglect, said Sarah Taylor, president of the Crow Hill Association, which has lobbied successfully for new sewers, water lines and roads, new storefronts, trees and, soon, decorative, old-style street lamps. ''It's gorgeous, what they've done,'' she said of Mr. Brown and Ms. Boyle and their renovation. 
 Their first working winter -- 2002-2003 -- in the new space was brutal: drifts of snow sifted through a massive tarp draped hopefully over the hole where the roof used to be -- and where an aerie-like addition would soon sprout. The crew burned scrap wood in metal buckets, heating a brick every hour or so and passing it around. Ms. Boyle bought them all blue insulated Dickies overalls, so they worked like giant Smurfs amid the drifts. They'd hired three friends and three of their moving company's employees and formed a contracting company, Big Sue (bigsuellc@earthlink.net), named for Ms. Boyle. Mr. Brown is from Nashville, and in the habit of attaching a ''Big'' modifier to things he's fond of, Ms. Boyle said. (The preamble to that winter was eventful, too: they were married on Sept. 15, 2001, amid civic turmoil, and while wrangling permits, variances and cash.) 
 After demolishing the insides of both buildings all the way to the brick walls, the construction was precise and sometimes high-tech, to create six lofty apartments and one-ground floor studio in the ice house using as much recycled material as possible, and employing green technologies that Mr. Brown and Ms. Boyle researched. (The renovation of the second building, into commercial space, is just beginning.)
 Mr. Brown drew the plans, which were edited and stamped by an engineer. The apartments, some on two levels, range between 1,100 and 1,450 square feet, and will rent for $1,650 to $1,950 a month starting in October. Their own apartment, as modishly gritty as the others -- a play of steel and brick and encompassing the roof addition -- is about 3,000 square feet. 
 The building's own timber, harvested from 300 massive beams, was repurposed for flooring, shelves, and door and window frames -- and an 11-by-5-foot island in their own open kitchen. They bought recycled claw-foot bathtubs and pedestal sinks from a local architectural salvage company.
 Radiant heat fixtures are laid under glazed concrete floors constructed from fly ash (a byproduct of burning coal); solar panels on the new roof provide as much as 50 percent of the building's energy.
 As cities grapple with the benefits of green building, state and federal agencies have begun offering incentives. Mr. Brown and Ms. Boyle have been awarded a $75,000 Keyspan ''Cinderella'' grant for green technologies, a $2,500 award from the New York City Green Building Design competition, and a $28,000 grant from the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority. They are awaiting certification from the United States Green Buildings Council and have begun work as consultants on other green-building projects.
 The only consultant they called on was Katrin Scholz-Barth, a specialist in planting green roofs. These are a delight, planted with alpine sedum and, on the topmost roof, interspersed with lavender, chives and thyme. Their moisture-holding leaves, which make them nearly maintenance free, save sewers from being overtaxed by the run-off of new developments; the spiky carpets can lower the temperature of a building -- and a neighborhood -- by seven degrees or more.
 The couple agreed early on to hash out every construction detail, aspiring to an aesthetic and marital democracy. Their living quarters flaunt casement windows on one side and double-hung mullioned ones on the other: his and her windows. ''I'm the casement guy,'' Mr. Brown said.

HEADLINE: Entrepreneurial Success via the Internet

BYLINE: By David Koeppel. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
IT took the death of his business partner at 21 last November for Josh Mohrer to get serious about trying to make their fledgling internet business a success. 
 Mr. Mohrer, now 22, and Elie Schwartz met as 12-year olds, and forged a friendship that took them from summer camp to ''Rational Fashion,'' the online business they started last year when they were in college.
 It was not only Mr. Schwartz's youth but the circumstances of his death that shocked Mr. Mohrer and everyone who knew them. He is said to have taken hallucinogenic mushrooms at an off-campus party and accidentally fallen from a third-story window. 
 ''Josh transmuted a tragedy into personal and business growth,'' says Jay Michaelson, 34, a friend and mentor and a founder of Wasabi Systems, a technology company based in Norfolk, Va. ''He could have easily folded the business, but he didn't.''
 Mr. Mohrer, a 2004 graduate of a joint degree program at Columbia University and the Jewish Theological Seminary, decided to continue building a company that primarily sells Ralph Lauren Polo shirts and other designer clothes on eBay and its own Rationalfashion.com Web site. As its sole employee, Mr. Mohrer runs most aspects of the business from his one-room apartment on the Upper West Side. 
 Mr. Mohrer became a math major to stand out from the pack of business students, and traveled the world as part of an a cappella band that performed Jewish folk music. Rational Fashion's flexibility allows him daily bike rides in Central Park and occasional business conducted at Starbucks.
 While Rational Fashion began in earnest last summer, Mr. Mohrer has devoted most of his time to it only since graduation. He has become an eBay gold power seller, a prestigious rank among merchants who do high-volume business and get overwhelmingly positive feedback from customers.
 ''I got a note from a customer that said 'Tell Josh in customer service he's doing a great job,''' he recalled. ''I don't tell them Josh is only one guy. Some people prefer to see it as a big operation. Not some kid in New York.''
 That ''kid from New York,'' who grew up in Queens, derives inspiration from the computer mogul Michael Dell, who also started his business in modest circumstances.
 MR. MOHRER estimates that Rational Fashion's sales in its first full year of business should total about $165,000, an average of $14,000 per month. Since graduation, he has averaged less than that: $10,000 in May, $11,000 in June, $8,000 in July and $12,000 from July 15 to Aug. 15.
 When he and Mr. Schwartz started selling clothes online in 2003, they were part of a new wave of entrepreneurs, according to a study published by researchers at Babson College. After two years of decline, entrepreneurial activity increased from 10.5 percent in 2002 to 11.9 percent in 2003.
 The researchers discovered that many of the start-ups were similar to Rational Fashion. Most were replicating existing goods or service businesses, with fewer than five employees. Forty percent of the owners were self-employed and 15.7 percent were men between the ages of 25 to 34.
 But there are plenty of advantages to youth, according to Suzanne Isack, the director of the National Institute for Entrepreneurship, a group that works with college and universities to promote entrepreneurial endeavors.
 ''I think it's important to balance idealism and passion for what they're doing, peppered with just enough realism,'' Ms. Isack tells young entrepreneurs like Mr. Mohrer.
 Bruce Weinberg, an associate professor of marketing and e-commerce at Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., believes that selling online is a great way for an entrepreneur to begin a career. He said that overhead for businessmen like Mr. Mohrer was low and that the apparel industry, one of the hottest sectors, was expected to gross between $10 billion and $12 billion in 2004.
 Mr. Mohrer is already thinking about the future. He would like to entice brick and mortar businesses to use him as a middleman, to sell their goods online. Rational Fashion would ''generate revenue through some kind of commission,'' and the businesses would benefit from his customer base and impressive eBay feedback ratings.
 He is also considering using his present business model to venture into another market, or even to work as a consultant or to earn an M.B.A. What he says he will never do is run his own brick and mortar store.
 ''That's never going to happen,'' he said. ''It's the opposite of what I want to do. It's irrational.''

HEADLINE: At Troubled Adult Home, a Troubled New Boss

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Ocean House, a 125-bed repository of last resort for New York City's impoverished mentally ill, and its dispiriting history are not all that remarkable in the world of the state's adult homes.
 Eight years ago, its operator went to prison for stealing residents' money and using the accounts of the home, which is in Queens, as a personal million-dollar slush fund. The state then inexplicably let his brother-in-law, a disgraced lawyer with no mental-health credentials, take over. Last month, he pleaded guilty to a scheme to steal more than $2 million from the home. 
 And now, though the Pataki administration has vowed to reform the state's adult home system, the new operator it installed at Ocean House also has a checkered background. The adult home he runs in Albany was recently cited by inspectors for violations that endangered residents, and last fall, officials seized two nursing homes he operated in Connecticut after charging widespread financial malfeasance, including the mishandling of residents' and workers' money. 
 Connecticut officials are conducting a civil inquiry into the nursing homes and the operator, Meyer Weber. Asked about Mr. Weber, the Connecticut attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, said in an interview, ''Our experience with his nursing homes in Connecticut would give us great reservations about his operating any other homes.''
 The change at Ocean House raises concerns about the Pataki administration's commitment to ensure that competent operators of good character run the adult homes, an issue that arose decades ago after the state drastically scaled back its psychiatric wards and had nowhere to place discharged patients. 
 More than 100 privately run adult homes in New York State shelter 15,000 mentally ill people, and the system has long been troubled. Residents who are so ill that they are unable to dress themselves wander the halls at all hours unsupervised, janitors are sometimes discovered distributing medication, and state regulation has often proven lax. 
 For years, residents died under questionable circumstances without any inquiries by the state, and negligent operators went unpunished. Mental-health experts portray the homes as little more than psychiatric flop houses.
 Asked whether it had reviewed Mr. Weber's record and was aware of what had happened in Connecticut, the State Health Department said through a spokesman, Robert Kenny, that Mr. Weber had been granted only a temporary license at Ocean House and that his application for a permanent one was pending. Mr. Kenny acknowledged the problems at Mr. Weber's Albany home, Pearl of Wisdom.
 ''We are concerned with the investigative findings in our latest inspection of the Pearl of Wisdom adult home, and we continue to closely monitor the situation to ensure that residents are receiving quality service and care,'' he said. ''We are now completing an extensive review of the latest surveillance in the case, as well as the temporary operator's (Weber's) track record as an operator of health care facilities in other states. This information will serve as a significant factor in our decision.''
 The department allowed Mr. Weber to take over the Albany home in November 2003, a month after officials in Connecticut had taken over his nursing homes there, records show. Two months ago, New York inspectors issued a scathing report on the 88-bed Albany home, charging that its medication practices were so inept and disorganized that residents' lives were in danger. One resident, for example, missed 28 doses of a drug used to treat seizures. Despite the report, Mr. Weber was installed at Ocean House this month.
 A reporter who went to Ocean House last week to survey conditions was escorted from the home by Mr. Weber and one of the home's supervisors, who said they would not allow a visit. The supervisor also made clear to a resident being interviewed that the resident should end the interview, which he immediately did.
 In front of the home, which is on Heyson Road in Far Rockaway not far from the beach, Mr. Weber said he would not discuss his record. ''You will have to deal with my attorney,'' he said.
 His lawyer, M. Joshua Aber, also would not respond to questions about Mr. Weber's record. Asked about Mr. Weber's qualifications, Mr. Aber said, ''He's presented them to the state and they have reviewed them.''
 State officials in Connecticut had no such reluctance to talk about Mr. Weber, who ran the nursing homes there with another operator. Last fall, the officials took the unusual step of getting a court order to seize the homes, Coleman Park in Bridgeport, which has 123 beds, and Rosewood in Waterbury, which has 84 beds. They documented what they said were numerous financial problems that left the two homes near collapse and jeopardized ''the health, safety and welfare'' of residents.
 According to court records, the homes had more than $3 million in liabilities, issued paychecks that bounced, and failed to pay property taxes, utilities and vendors. Investigators charged that tens of thousands of dollars in residents' accounts had been transferred to the homes' operating accounts and that the homes collected money from workers for health insurance without providing coverage.
 At one point, Connecticut Light and Power asked the Connecticut Department of Public Health to move residents from Rosewood because it wanted to cut off its electricity because of unpaid bills, the records show. Money was then apparently paid to keep the power on.
 Workers at Coleman Park told the state that they even used their own money to pay for health care supplies like gloves and adult diapers.
 ''The nursing homes were financial wrecks,'' Mr. Blumenthal, the attorney general, said.
 Brian Courtney, a Connecticut lawyer representing Mr. Weber in the nursing home cases, said his client disputed some of the allegations but ultimately agreed to the state takeover. He blamed the Connecticut state government for many of Mr. Weber's problems, saying that it had not provided sufficient Medicaid money to run nursing homes that served needy populations.
 ''I am not aware that there were ever any issues with patient care,'' Mr. Courtney said. ''We are talking about dollars here. They were wonderful operators as far as I know. They did their best trying to manage these homes in a very difficult economic climate.'' He said any money transferred from residents' accounts had been restored.
 Still, the allegations against the homes would resonate with anyone who has examined the history of Ocean House. In two reports nearly a decade apart, a New York State watchdog agency, the Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled, has documented a sweeping array of misdeeds at the home.
 The first report, issued in 1992 when the home was called Hi-Li Manor, was titled, ''Exploiting the Vulnerable.'' The report said the home's operator, Beryl Zyskind, improperly diverted millions of dollars in revenue from the home, which is technically a nonprofit entity. The money went to investments, interest-free loans, excessive salaries, tuition payments for relatives, jewelry and furs, the report said. Mr. Zyskind also stole $120,000 from a resident who had received the money in back veteran's benefits. As a result of the report, Mr. Zyskind was convicted on federal charges and sentenced to 30 months in prison. His brother-in-law, Sherman Taub, then took over, though he was a lawyer who had resigned from the bar after being accused of billing his law clients $232,000 for his personal expenses.
 Mr. Taub renamed the home Ocean House and wasted little time in following in Mr. Zyskind's footsteps, according to court records and a second report by the quality of care commission. That report, issued in December 2001, detailed how Mr. Taub had engaged in a scheme to siphon more than $2 million from the home through improper mortgage transactions and other maneuvers.
 All the while, inspectors said, conditions at Ocean House were among the worst in New York. They found rooms infested with cockroaches, residents sleeping on soiled sheets, the kitchen floor rotted and widespread hazardous conditions because of a dilapidated structure and poorly supervised renovations.
 After pleading guilty in July in a case brought by the Manhattan district attorney's office, Mr. Taub is facing one to three years in prison.
 At Ocean House, residents said Mr. Taub would not be missed. ''You would say hello to him, and he would not even acknowledge that you were there,'' said a resident, Gary Levin. 
 Others said that whatever Mr. Weber's record, they wanted changes, especially more security. They said that at night, strangers entered the home, dealt drugs and drank alcohol, making some residents afraid to leave their rooms.
 ''Things have been getting more and more broken down here,'' said Ernest Nelson, vice president of the residents council. ''We all hope that he is going to improve things.''

HEADLINE: Delegates In, Commuters Out

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
WHEN Amy Walsh of Commack heard a few months ago that the Republican National Convention would be held at Madison Square Garden beginning Aug. 30, she quickly booked her vacation for that week.
 ''I'm going to Cancun to stay away from the convention,'' Ms. Walsh, a legal secretary for Icahn Associates at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, said as she waited at the Deer Park railroad station one recent morning for the 7:47 to Penn Station. ''I'm concerned about the commute and the fact that there might be some terrorist acts. I'm scared.'' 
 Ms. Walsh said she was furious that the convention was being held in the city. ''They shouldn't be doing this in New York,'' she said. ''It's a very bad decision. Why pick us after everything we've been through? Why put us in that position?'' 
 The terrorists aren't talking and the anti-government protesters who will descend on the city are being vague. The job of the security personnel is clear: to prevent the other two groups from disrupting the convention and the web of business and transportation that surrounds the Garden. But no matter which of the three groups has the greatest impact when the convention comes, it seems inevitable that travel into and around Midtown will be a headache, and many Long Islanders are planning to avoid it. 
 In interviews with 19 commuters who take the Long Island Rail Road to Manhattan, only one said he was planning to go to work that week as usual through Penn Station. Five others said they would be working in the city that week but would avoid Penn Station, which is under Madison Square Garden, by changing to the subway in Jamaica, Queens, or in downtown Brooklyn.
 But most commuters said they were going on vacation or planned to work from home or from their company's Long Island offices. 
 ''I'm basically working from home, on the computer and the phone,'' said Neil Margolies of Dix Hills, who works in the garment district. ''You have to be crazy to go in. I'm not going into that ridiculous problem that's going to occur. There are going to be enormous problems in walking out the right exits at Penn Station.''
 He was referring to the Aug. 30-Sept. 2 closure of four of the six entrances to Penn Station. All access will be through the entrances at 32nd Street and Seventh Avenue and at 34th Street just west of Seventh Avenue.
 James Dermody, president of the Long Island Rail Road, said he had been assured that there would be plenty of police officers ''to blanket the place'' and declared, ''Penn Station is going to be the safest place in the City of New York.''
 People may be safe and still face big delays getting to work, but Mr. Dermody said there would also be railroad employees on hand to help direct crowds. ''We have made detailed plans in order to have customer assistance and crowd control to get people to their trains as conveniently as possible with little or no extra time,'' he said. 
 Mr. Dermody noted that the railroad put a flyer and a wallet-size map of Penn Station on every seat to explain which entrances will remain open. And he said there would be new directional signs posted in Penn Station for L.I.R.R. passengers as well as for Amtrak and New Jersey Transit riders who face the same restricted access to the station.
 Mr. Dermody said that the week before the Labor Day weekend is usually a heavy vacation week anyway. ''We've been looking at travel patterns for that week and I don't think there will be major problems other than if there is a security problem like an unidentified package,'' he said. ''We have campaigns on now asking customers and employees that if they see something, say something. It is trying to get everyone in the frame of mind to be secure and not to leave their own packages unattended.''
 Delays may begin well before Penn Station, because every train bound for Midtown will be searched by the police before it begins its run. The police will ride every train into the city and additional officers -- some with bomb-sniffing dogs -- may board at Jamaica or Woodside.
 But Mr. Dermody said the plan was to have ''enough manpower around to minimize delay.'' 
 ''And if there is a delay,'' he added, ''we'll have enough customer information assistance people around to let customers know what is going on, whether in New York or other areas. We are trying to make it as seamless as possible for our commuters.''
 Few commuters are mollified.
 Kathy Rupp of St. James said she arranged her vacation for convention week because the city ''is going to be a nightmare.''
 ''I think the commute is going to be terrible,'' she said. ''It's not that I think there is going to be a terrorist attack, but the protests and stuff like that are going to make it very difficult to maneuver through this town.''
 Ms. Rupp, who works at a law firm in Midtown, said she planned to spend the week with her family on Long Island, either at home or on day trips nearby. And that in turn might help the Long Island economy.
 ''If you take a vacation and spend time on Long Island, you might be a tourist in your own backyard, maybe going to Long Island's art galleries or vineyards,'' said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a business group. ''And if you work from home, you might go to a local restaurant for lunch or take your wife out for dinner.''
 Some Manhattanites are also planning to go to the Island to escape the hubbub. Barry Shatoff, general manager of the Southampton Inn, said some guests were booking rooms during the convention expressly to avoid subway disruptions, street demonstrations and crowded restaurants. But Mike Johnston, president of the Long Island Hotel Association, said hotel bookings for the week were not unusually high.
 More of what Dr. Kamer called the ''back-door impact'' might come from a rise in retail purchases by those staying on the Island.
 Janine Nebons, a spokeswoman for the Tanger Outlet Center in Riverhead, said that for the last two weeks it ran advertisements in the city designed to lure New Yorkers -- particularly those who have second homes on the Island -- to its 168 stores, the vast majority of which are manufacturers' outlets.
 ''I think a lot of people knew the convention was coming and they shifted their plans to try to stay out of the city,'' she said, pointing out that the number of bus reservations by groups going to the center from Brooklyn and Queens is higher for that week than it was during the comparable period in prior years.
 Ms. Nebons said that the week before Labor Day weekend was already one of the biggest sale weeks of the year because of the annual tax-free week Aug. 31 through Sept. 6 on all clothing and shoes up to $110. Both the state and Suffolk County are participating in the tax-free week; Nassau isn't.
 The Long Island Convention & Visitors Bureau and Sports Commission is trying to attract some of the 4,800 Republican delegates and alternates to visit Long Island before they return home.
 Gloria Rocchio, the group's chairwoman, said e-mail messages were being sent to all of the delegates telling them of some of the special trip packages that had been arranged for them. In addition, each delegate will receive a package in his or her hotel room from the bureau that contains its travel guide to Long Island and further details about such attractions as a day trip to Stony Brook or to the annual Shinnecock Pow-Wow in Southampton.
 ''I believe they would come after the convention rather than before, and I don't believe they can come during the convention because security is going to be so tight,'' Ms. Rocchio said.
 Any delegates who make it out to the Island will have plenty of company. One commuter who declined to give his name said that his office is above 2 Penn Station and that his company is allowing him to work from home because he feared ''it's going to be crazy here.''
 ''I have an office in my home with a cable hookup to the office,'' he said. ''I'm also planning to hold business meetings outside of the office.''
 Edward J. Brucia of Stony Brook, vice president of Bradley Marketing Group, said that because his Midtown office might be difficult to get to as a result of anticipated street closures, the company's five employees who live on Long Island would be permitted to work from the company's Hauppauge office.
 ''We've decided that unless there is an emergency, we'll handle our accounts out here,'' he said as he walked from the parking lot to the Deer Park station.
 But staying on Long Island is not a choice for Frank Pomarico of Dix Hills, a consultant for Citigroup.
 ''As a consultant I don't get paid if I don't go to work,'' he said.
 He said he planned to take the E subway train from Jamaica rather than ride into Penn Station as usual.
 Kristina Hinckson of Massapequa, an administrative assistant in Manhattan, said she planned to change at Jamaica for the train to Brooklyn during the convention week. She said she had thought of taking the week off, ''but I'm going to be brave and stick it out.''
 ''I don't want the terrorists to totally derail my normal daily routine,'' she said. 
 Asked if she was more concerned with terrorism than congestion, Ms. Hinckson replied, ''Yes, because I really think that the Republican convention could be an attractive terrorist target.''
 But Wendy S. Delmater of Bay Shore, who said she planned to avoid Penn Station and had been trying different subway and bus alternatives to get to her job as a safety manager for Total Safety Consulting on Staten Island, said her main concern was gridlock. 
 ''It's not that I don't think it will be safe,'' she said. ''The problem is that it's going to be a zoo.''

HEADLINE: Battle Lines Are Drawn Over Merlot

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
A DEBATE about image that could have far-reaching consequences for Long Island's wine industry is brewing among major producers.
 A handful of winemakers and executives, representing their wineries' owners, have begun forming a trade organization, the East End Merlot Alliance, that would promote merlot as the Island's premier grape and wine.
 Opponents call their mission too narrow and possibly commercially harmful and say that the region's 35 producers, represented by the Long Island Wine Council, should continue to emphasize the diversity of their red and white wines. The issue arose in the council last week. 
 The nascent merlot alliance consists of Raphael, Bedell and Pellegrini on the North Fork and Wolffer on the South Fork. 
 Early dissenters, who are not organized, are Paumanok, Palmer, Lenz and Castello di Borghese (successor of the Hargrave Vineyard, which started the industry in 1973) on the North Fork. 
 Commenting as an owner of Castello di Borghese, and not the council, of which he is president, Marco Borghese said he preferred an islandwide marketing policy that generally emphasized that ''we are growing French vinifera grapes successfully.'' But expressing a live-and-let-live sentiment, he also allowed that anything that drew attention to the region ''would be fantastic.''
 Mr. Borghese said he could not tell if an alliance would fracture the council and its broad-based membership and promotional interests.
 Richard Olsen-Harbich, Raphael's winemaker and managing director, and a newcomer, Trent Preszler, Bedell's vice president of operations, fathered the alliance idea.
 With 26 years of winegrowing experience on the Island, Mr. Olsen-Harbich carries weight among his colleagues. He was pivotal in researching, drafting and lobbying for the federal regulations establishing the Island's three American Viticultural Areas, or appellations.
 Mr. Preszler, who holds a master's degree in agricultural economics from Cornell University. His master's thesis, published in 2002, is about marketing New York wines in New York City, where East End wines struggle for acceptance among retailers, restaurateurs and consumers.
 Both men have drafted an introductory letter, to be mailed soon, inviting East End wineries to join the group. Asserting that the alliance would complement and not compete with the council, the signers find Long Island's image at a crossroads. 
 ''Our ability to sell premium wines to a sophisticated audience is no longer inhibited by the quality of our wines or age of our vines,'' they say. ''Instead, we face price resistance and consumer confusion resulting from the lack of a focused brand identity.''
 The alliance, they say, would address this problem ''by answering the question, 'What do we do best?''' It would share ''a common belief in the East End'' as ''the No.1 merlot appellation in the New World'' and would emphasize ''self-regulated quality standards.'' 
 Citing Oregon pinot noir and Napa cabernet sauvignon, the founders say: ''We believe the proper way to develop our reputation is to follow the example of other great wine regions and promote one varietal. We believe this focus on one varietal does not take away from our excellence in various other wines.'' 
 They observe that merlot is the only red grape that achieves complete ripeness yearly. Cornell research, they say, ''shows that the East End's climate and soil topography'' is similar ''to that of Bordeaux -- the No.1 merlot-producing region in the world.''
 Conventional wisdom holds that another Bordeaux grape, cabernet franc, could rival merlot locally. But the letter says, ''We do not believe cab franc possesses the consistency, character or long-term consumer interest to merit a regional flagship marketing focus.''
 About 3,000 acres on the Island are covered with vines, of which at least 666 are merlot and 209 are cabernet franc, the council estimates.
 Among those signing the invitation to join were Peggy Lauber, Bedell's executive vice president for sales and marketing; Roman Roth, Wolffer's winemaker and general manager; Russell Hearn, Pellegrini's winemaker; and Benjamin Sisson, Raphael's vineyard manager. Their estates, particularly Raphael, have deep stakes in merlot.
 Dissenting, Charles Massoud, a Paumanok owner, said that seeking to transform their estates' dominant interest into the region's marquee identity ''could be seen as self-serving and divisive.''
 ''A marketing strategy that would try to promote our region as a merlot region is shortsighted, is based on bad marketing and factually incorrect,'' he said. Acknowledging that ''merlot does very well,'' he argued that other grapes ''do as well, if not better, sometimes.'' 
 Urging public debate, Mr. Massoud said: ''Gambling our region's reputation on merlot is not a risk worth taking. Ten years ago, had we been thinking this way, we might have tried to be seen as a chardonnay region. With the rug being pulled out from under the chardonnay market, it would not look smart today if we had done that, even though we have some wonderful chardonnay grown out here. Many restaurateurs have told me they see a softening in the demand for merlot and a firming up of demand for red blends and cabernet sauvignon and syrah.''
 Mr. Massoud would prefer a council campaign that emphasized the Island's wine spectrum. About 30 types of grapes are farmed locally, he said, ''and we can point to an excellent wine made from almost each and every one.'' He singled out such reds as syrah, cabernet sauvignon and pinot noir and such whites as chenin blanc and riesling (both strong Paumanok suits), pinot blanc, sauvignon blanc and gewurztraminer. 
 Robert J. Palmer, a Palmer Vineyards owner who has spent a lifetime in advertising and marketing, found the alliance approach ''too limiting'' and wondered: ''Why build yourself into a corner? People do this all the time in marketing, and sometimes you are stuck with it.'' Merlot's high point on the Island has passed, he said, and he plans to uproot four acres of merlot vines and plant chardonnay.
 Lenz considered joining, and Eric Fry, its winemaker, signed the group's letter. But later Peter Carroll, an owner, felt skeptical about the prospective content and enforceability of quality controls and said he preferred to let market forces define the region's representative wines. 
 Mr. Olsen-Harbich said he was not daunted by the prospect that merlot might decline in favor, as wines do cyclically. ''The wine of the day is going to change,'' he predicted. ''But climate and soil are not going to change, at least that quickly. Frankly, I don't care what the market does. I am looking at it from a wine-quality perspective.''

HEADLINE: What Drives Consumer Confidence?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
WITH crude oil near $50 a barrel, consumer confidence could be in for a big hit. James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J.P. Morgan, thinks otherwise. 
 ''My gasoline station manager didn't know that the price of oil was near $50 a barrel,'' Mr. Glassman said. ''He just knows what the oil company charges him for gasoline when the delivery truck pulls up each night.'' That price has been dropping. 
 The national average price of a gallon of midgrade gasoline reached $2.155 in May. It has since dropped to $1.97, according to the Department of Energy.
 Consumer confidence had already been weakened by gasoline prices, Mr. Glassman said, and has actually recovered. ''The good news is that this is probably already behind us,'' he said.
 In May -- the month of gasoline's recent price peak -- the University of Michigan index of consumer sentiment dropped 4.2 percent, to 90.2, from 94.2 in April. It bounced back to 96.7 in July and then fell to 94 in the preliminary confidence report for August. 
 And the forecast is that the index will stay at that level when the final figure is reported on Friday, according to Bloomberg News. 
 But while oil and gasoline may not be major factors in setting consumer confidence right now, job growth may be, depending on the message consumers are receiving.
 In May, the Conference Board's consumer confidence index, the other consumer barometer on which financial markets focus, was unchanged as a pickup in job growth offset the climb in gasoline prices, according to Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's research center. 
 By July, the Conference Board index had risen for four consecutive months and was at its highest since June 2002. 
 ''The spring turnaround has been fueled by gains in employment, and unless the job market sours, consumer confidence should continue to post solid numbers,'' Ms. Franco said in the July news release.
 So what did the consumer hear about jobs? That only 32,000 payroll jobs were created in July, as reported by the Labor Department? Or that 629,000 jobs were added, based on its household survey?
 ''Consumers paid attention to the weaker payroll report for July,'' said Richard T. Curtin, director of surveys of consumers at the University of Michigan. And that helped to drag down the consumer sentiment level in Michigan's preliminary confidence report for August.

HEADLINE: The Rush to Buy A Piece of Paradise

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS GRUDIN

DATELINE: MAUI, Hawaii 

 BODY:
FROM the pool of their six-bedroom home on Keawakapu Beach, Doug and Mary Hajjar enjoy a sweeping view of three islands, uninterrupted but for some lanky palms. In 1997, they spent about $5 million building the winter getaway, complete with an aqua shingle roof, a winding glass staircase and a 60-inch TV that retracts into the family room floor. In today's market, the 6,000-square-foot home would command up to $15 million.
 The Hajjars, who first visited Maui while he was stationed in Vietnam, have an almost identical home in Cape Cod, Mass., but the Maui mansion is their favorite. 
 ''We think we have one of the best places in the world,'' said Mr. Hajjar, who made his fortune starting and selling technology companies in Silicon Valley. ''The weather is incredible and the beach is spectacular. Twice now we've seen whales give birth right in front of the house, just 50 or 100 yards off the shore.''
 The Hajjars are not alone in their good fortune. Since 1998, a gold rush mentality has taken hold of Maui's housing market -- which now has more licensed Realtors than available listings -- and its prospectors have been handsomely rewarded. The median price of a home on the island jumped from $265,000 in the first seven months of 1998 to $539,000 during the same period this year, according to figures compiled by the Realtors Association of Maui. And coveted beachfront properties like the Hajjars' have increased by even higher multiples. 
 ''It's pervasive; the real estate market has been booming in all ends,'' said Leroy Laney, a professor of finance and economics at Hawaii Pacific University and an economic consultant for First Hawaiian Bank. ''There was a good bit of pent-up demand here, locally as well as offshore.''
 While Hawaii home prices have climbed steadily in recent years, the trend has been most pronounced on Maui, the second-largest island, blessed with some of the most coveted beaches in the world as well as a wide variety of other attractions. From the posh shorefront resorts, to the rainy bamboo forests of Hana, to the 10,000-foot Haleakala Crater, the Valley Isle, as the island is also known, is a vaunted destination for golfers and retirees as well as naturalists and adventurers.
 Capitalizing on the exposure from tourism, Maui's real estate market seems finally to be catching up to its priceless beauty, spurred on by many of the same factors that have pushed some mainland housing prices to record levels: low interest rates, the retirement of wealthy baby boomers and a limited supply of property, according to Paul H. Brewbaker, chief economist for Bank of Hawaii. ''A number of these elements started to come together in the late 90's and the timing was right for realignment and renewed appreciation,'' he said.
 Bob Cella is another beneficiary of Maui's boom. In 1995, the Philadelphia native bought Coldwell Banker of Maui. The company's 11 agents sold about $50 million worth of property in 1996. By 2003, nearly 100 Coldwell brokers racked up $980 million in sales.
 ''You can sit back and think you did it, but the market did 50 percent of the work,'' Mr. Cella said. ''For the buyer who wants this type of product, they have plenty of money. They buy one of these condos for a couple million dollars and obviously the product is not worth that, but the lifestyle certainly is.'' 
 Across the island -- whether it's the bucolic ''up-country'' communities like Kula and Makawao or the golf resorts at Kapalua, Kaanipali and Wailea -- nearly everyone who bought property in the last six years has doubled his money, or better.
 Sitting in their sun-drenched oceanfront living room, Jeff and June Mair can attest to that. The California retirees came to Maui in 2001, and their 4,800-square-foot custom home -- which cost $2.95 million for land and construction -- is now worth more than $7 million.
 ''We bought the land for $1.55 million, and when escrow closed a month later, we could've sold it for $2 million,'' said Mr. Mair, evenly tanned from long hours of golf interspersed with ocean swims. 
 The rising property values have also brought along some undesired side effects. A shortage of affordable housing is one of Maui County's chief concerns, and residents worry about sustaining the environment, culture and lifestyle.
 ''Wherever it's beautiful and wonderful, it's changing so much that your head spins,'' said Hunton Conrad, a Hawaiian-born architectural designer who has worked on Maui for the past 26 years. ''In places near the ocean, most of the architecture now reflects a Newport Beach mentality.'' 
 One of the most striking reflections of the market's hasty leap can be found a short stroll from Doug and Mary Hajjar's place along Keawakapu Beach, where several $10-million-plus mansions have crowded out the understated cottages and ranch-style homes that once lined the shore. Towering over a westward ocean view, a 27,800-square-foot orange stucco mansion -- designed by the Mexican architect Ricardo Legorreta -- is a boxy beacon of contemporary luxury.
 ''We were very upset about that house, that thing,'' said Jacqueline Tavares, 65, whose father bought several lots on Keawakapu in the 1940's, when wild pigs still wandered the sandy terrain. Mrs. Tavares and her husband, Howard, 71, say they are the only original landowners along the South Kihei Beach, which, like much of Maui, has become too expensive for locals to afford.
 But as clear as the flat orange lines of the Legorreta house against the blue ocean is the allure of buying one's own piece of paradise, something the latest crop of Maui homeowners have shown a willingness to pay for.
 ''It's your own private magical space, which is hard to find anywhere,'' Mr. Hajjar said. ''I've traveled all over the world and I've never found a space that makes you feel like that.''

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on Aug. 22 with an article about Maui misidentified the architect of a large house fronted by palm trees, an example of very expensive houses being built in the area. It was designed by Thomas A. Kligerman of Ike Kligerman Barkley Architects in Manhattan, not by Ricardo Legorreta.

HEADLINE: Rain as the Rainmaker

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: OCEAN GROVE 

 BODY:
LEN STEEN the owner of Nagle's, an old-fashioned ice cream parlor on Main Avenue here -- was expecting the worst. Dairy prices were doubling, vanilla prices were tripling and the economy was not recovering quickly enough. Fortunately, the Farmer's Almanac was predicting lousy weather.
 It's now late August, and not much has changed. The cost of an ice cream is in no danger of dropping. And precipitation levels for the summer are about an inch-and-a-half above normal. 
 ''Well, I don't want to sound unnecessarily Reaganistic,'' Mr. Steen said. ''You know, like a new dawn in America, but this has been one fantastic year. Anybody complaining about the weather or the economy this summer, well, they must be seeing something I'm not.''
 Each summer, the New Jersey shore can expect slightly more than 11 inches of rain in June, July and August, according to the National Weather Service. Last year, the skies opened for about two inches more than normal, and because it actually rained on 41 of the 92 days in those three months, 2003 was generally considered a washout for people fleeing the stifling cities for a week or so of sun, sand and shore dinners.
 This summer, through mid-August, rainfall at the shore was about 1.5 inches above normal, but over fewer days. As of midweek, it had rained on only 29 days.
 But washout? It's all a matter of perspective, and the dirty little secret among business owners down the shore is that they like it to rain -- at least a little bit. The reasoning goes like this: The visitors are coming to the shore, rain or shine -- barring a hurricane -- because they have already booked their motel rooms or leased their houses or condos. The check has been written and cashed. Once they are down the shore, rain will drive people off the beach and onto the streets lined with shops teeming with tchotchkes, towels, bathing suits, sweatshirts, Italian ice, books and anything else fit for human consumption. 
 ''This was a great year for us,'' said Kim Miller, who with her husband, Josh, owns Ocean Galleries, pricey art emporiums in Avalon and Stone Harbor. ''Why, am I supposed to tell you differently? Am I supposed to complain? Sure, it rains. So on those days, people come in during the day. When it doesn't rain, they go to the beach and then visit at night. It's the shore. What do merchants expect?''
 Well, Jenn Heinold, the director of marketing at the Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts in Cape May, which runs tours out of Cape May, says shore merchants expect 2002 -- when the economy boomed -- every year.
 ''That was the great year,'' said Ms. Heinold, whose center also operates four souvenir stores. ''The weather was great. The economy was great. We got spoiled.''
 She added: ''We're flat from last year, and that was down considerably from 2002. We were hoping for a comeback, but it hasn't happened.''
 Ms. Heinold has noticed over the years that rain -- or at least overcast skies -- has often helped tour numbers and lighthouse visits. This summer, the tours and activities for families -- like Kids Day at the Victorian Emlen Physick Estate and the Cape May Kids Playhouse -- have been way up.
 ''If it rains here, people seem to be really looking for something for the family this year,'' Ms. Heinold said. ''But you can't blame everything on rain. It hasn't been all that bad.''
 On the other hand, rainy days take their toll at the new Mid-Atlantic Center business, the Doo-Wop Museum Shop on the Schellenger Avenue amusement pier in Wildwood. It opened this year under the pier's roller-coaster, selling items reminiscent of the 1950's and 1960's heyday of Wildwood.
 ''When it rains, the whole pier closes, so we don't do any business at all,'' Ms. Heinold said. ''So we were a little disappointed. But we'll figure things out by next summer there.''
 A little farther north, on the boardwalk in Ocean City, it was not frustration with the weather at the shore but the rain farther inland that drove business passions.
 ''We did just fine with weather down here,'' said John Oehlers, the manager of Mack and Manco's, a well-known pizza parlor at Ninth Avenue and the Boardwalk. ''It was all that rain in Burlington County and the predictions of hurricanes that kept people away. We depend a lot on day trippers and weekenders, so I think they just stayed away on those weeks. Otherwise, though, it wasn't too bad. It's got to rain sometime, right?''
 There was really only one washout weekend -- last Friday through Sunday -- with dueling tropical storms churning their way up the coast.
 ''Every other Saturday night, we were able to have our piano player outside from 8 p.m. until the last person went home, which was never before 11,'' Mr. Steen of Nagle's said. ''It only rained 8 days out of 31 in July. You can't do better than that. We held the line on prices, even with the dairy going through the roof. I guess people appreciated that and just ordered more.''
 Down the street, even on a Monday afternoon, customers were jamming the Ocean Grove Flower and Gift Shop.
 ''I don't have time to talk,'' a shop clerk, who declined to identify herself, said on a misty Monday morning last week. ''It's been just busy all summer. I don't want to seem short. It's just that it has been a good day every day.''
 Mr. Steen couldn't agree more.
 ''It's Monday and we're full,'' he said. ''Business people who complain about the weather at the shore should go to Seattle. It's a great life here.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Expects a Role in Najaf, But Says Iraq Calls the Shots

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
Senior officials in the Bush administration have said all week that the decision to confront Moktada al-Sadr and his fighters in Najaf, and to use military force if necessary, will be made by Prime Minister Ayad Allawi and his government and by them alone.
 ''It's a problem that the Iraqi government is working to solve,'' Scott McClellan, the White House spokesman, said Thursday. ''They are the ones that are in charge of resolving this situation in Najaf.''
 According to the Bush administration, 3,500 Iraqi Army forces are trained to conduct an operation like removing the rebels from the shrine in Najaf where they have been holed up, and the Iraqis would carry out the major part of any operation. 
 But because any military action by Iraqi security forces would be backed by American air power and possibly by more direct military involvement, few specialists take the claims of sole Iraqi discretion at face value. Officials close to the situation say it is inconceivable that the administration will simply let Iraqi forces act in Najaf without a discussion and assent in Washington.
 ''The Iraqis are totally calling the ball,'' said a senior administration official involved in the discussions on Iraq. But he added, ''In the event of a significant difference over policy, I suspect the issue would be referred to senior levels in Washington.''
 From there it would be decided who would go to Dr. Allawi ''and express our concerns,'' he said, adding that such a sequence of events ''has not yet occurred'' with regard to Najaf or any other areas.
 The official's comments reflected an extremely delicate moment for the United States almost eight weeks after it turned sovereignty over to Iraq. The United States left 140,000 American troops to provide most of the nation's security while Iraqis are encouraged to come forward to be the face of their government, even though they lack the capacity to provide security for their people.
 In the administration, meanwhile, the Iraq Policy and Operations Group holds daily video conferences to discuss developments. The group includes top officials at the State and Defense Departments, the White House and the American Embassy in Baghdad.
 Some American officials say administration policy makers are haunted by missteps in Iraq when the United States was in charge under the occupation administrator, L. Paul Bremer III.
 Earlier sieges of rebels in Falluja, and military actions in Najaf and elsewhere, were accompanied by threats to use force to arrest and disarm rebels. In Falluja, the threats were rescinded and in Najaf, military actions were pressed without the arrest of Mr. Sadr out of concern about the possibility of igniting violent Iraqi protests.
 ''The situation has been bungled and agonized over from the beginning,'' said Larry Diamond, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University who advised Mr. Bremer in Baghdad.
 ''Bremer wanted to put Sadr out of business, but the military was wary about the cost and the difficulties,'' he added. ''It was a pathetic succession of debating, wavering, wondering, hesitating, planning and then backing off over many months.''
 A senior administration official, recalling the earlier false starts in confronting Mr. Sadr, said that it was decided that Iraqi forces needed to lead such a military action, and that they were not ready. Second, he said, the Iraqi government itself was not viewed by Iraqis as legitimate enough to make such a decision.
 Now, officials said, a new consensus in the Bush administration holds that Dr. Allawi has the legitimacy to order a military action against Mr. Sadr and that Dr. Allawi can draw on the hostility of Najaf residents over Mr. Sadr's use of the Imam Ali shrine, one of the most sacred mosques in the Islamic world, as a military base and arms depot.
 An official said the administration was still anxious about what might go wrong in any military action against Mr. Sadr and his forces, in the shrine or elsewhere in Najaf. 
 ''There's still a lot of doubt about how these Iraqis are going to perform in protecting themselves and avoiding casualties to noncombatants,'' an American official said. But he said there was also a feeling that not backing Dr. Allawi would undercut him and wreck his legitimacy and that of America.
 The feeling that now is the time to act appears to be shared by American allies in Iraq.
 ''If Allawi has accepted the necessity to use force, we have to have confidence in his judgment,'' Prime Minister Marek Belka of Poland said in an interview this month after meeting with President Bush.
 Mr. Belka, who for much of the last year was director of economic policy in Iraq for the occupation, added that the Sadr rebellion represented ''a fight for who will be the leader of the Shia community.''
 ''I don't think Polish military commanders will be unhappy to see the Sadrists attacked by the United States military,'' he added, referring to Polish forces in Iraq, many of whom are also stationed in the Najaf area. But he said that given the risks, Polish commanders were also probably happy not to be part of any operation attacking the shrine.
 Administration officials say that now is the time to deal with Mr. Sadr, by force if necessary. 
 ''Allawi thinks it's absolutely crucial for himself, and for the credibility of his government, to confront Moktada strongly and decisively, if possible with Iraqi forces in the foreground,'' a senior official said.
 Another official said the current situation ''indicates that the Iraq government under Mr. Allawi is determined to stamp out thugs and renegades who would use force against it.'' What happens in Najaf, he said, will ''send an important signal'' and presage possible actions or threats of force in other places.
 ''We'll see if the ones who are acting up in Basra follow suit,'' the official said. ''We'll see if force has to be used against them.''
 If force is considered, most authorities expect the decision to be carefully monitored in Washington even as policy makers step aside and contend that everything is up to the Iraqis.

LENGTH: 733 words

HEADLINE: That Not-So-Distant Thunder in the Bond Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
WHEN investors consider the bond market these days, the low level of interest rates should be more cause for worry than for gratitude. 
 Yes, despite forecasts of a surge in interest rates this year, long-term yields in the Treasury market are close to where they started in January. That has resulted in a return from the overall bond market of 2.5 percent through Friday, low but much better than expected -- and better than the stock market's losses. 
 But the bond market has been very volatile. Yields shot up earlier in the year, and even though they have since fallen, it would be risky to bet that the current climate will continue much longer. 
 There are plenty of reasons that rates should have risen much further by now. Federal Reserve policy makers have raised their benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point and intend to go higher. The price of crude oil is within striking distance of $50 a barrel. Consumer inflation, even after a surprising slip in July, has run at an annual rate of 3.7 percent since May. 
 A record federal budget deficit of more than $400 billion is predicted for this year. Although economic growth is not as robust as it was early in the year, many forecasters still expect a 3-percent-plus pace in the second half.
 The yields on shorter-term securities, like the two-year note, are up about six-tenths of a percentage point this year, but the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note has actually slipped by two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.23 percent. 
 One explanation is that Fed policy makers are moving slowly in raising their short-term interest rate target, the federal funds rate, which is holding back the rise in longer-term rates. The fed funds rate is ''the anchor for the entire yield curve,'' said Paul A. McCulley, a portfolio manager and economist at Pimco, an asset management company in Newport Beach, Calif.
 In addition, government data shows that the pace of growth slowed in the second quarter. High oil prices could continue to curb consumer spending, and therefore the growth of the entire economy.
 But this explanation has a problem: it requires investors to ignore the fact that persistently high oil prices can increase inflation. ''Just now oil is being treated as a tax on growth, not as inflationary, so it is not pushing rates higher,'' said Mary J. Miller, an assistant director of the fixed-income group at T. Rowe Price.
 If oil prices come down, the drag on consumer spending will disappear quickly. The prospect of stronger growth would probably send interest rates higher as investors bet on faster rate increases from the Fed. Longer-term interest rates may rise even if a drop in oil prices relieves inflationary pressure, because the Consumer Price Index, excluding energy, is still relatively high. It rose at a 2.6 percent annual rate in the six months ending in July. 
 For all these reasons, it is a big risk to bet on interest rates remaining low. 
 ''You are not supposed to be risk-seeking at these levels of interest rates,'' said Mr. McCulley of Pimco. It's too easy, he said, to end up in a ''nasty bear market.'' 
 Another surge in rates could be worse than the one earlier this year.
 On June 14, the yield on the Treasury's two-year note was up more than a full percentage point from the end of last year, to 2.93 percent, while the yield on the 10-year note was up 0.6 percentage points, to 4.87 percent. At that time, an investor in the overall Treasury market had lost 1.4 percent for the year. Investment-grade corporate bonds were down 1.7 percent, while high-yield junk bonds were up just 0.2 percent, according to the fixed-income indexes of Merrill Lynch. Since then, the yield on the 10-year note has dropped back to 4.23 percent, near its low point since the spring. Over the same period, the return from the overall bond market has been 3.9 percent. But this is the kind of whipsaw that bond investors want to avoid. 
 TO do that, investors need to be cautious, staying in shorter-term fixed-income securities, which would have a smaller price decline if rates moved higher.
 There is even an argument for keeping some cash in money market funds. Their rates are finally inching higher again as the Fed lifts its target for short-term rates.
 ''It might make some sense,'' said Ms. Miller of T. Rowe Price, ''to enjoy a modest return while the uncertainty in the bond and stock market plays out.''

HEADLINE: 'The Residential Is Hot, But the Commercial Is Not'

BYLINE: By LISA CHAMBERLAIN

 BODY:
FOR the better part of a year, Emeka Okafor and Todd Johnson have been struggling to open Le Cafe Starving Artiste in the heart of Bedford-Stuyvesant. The two Bed-Stuy residents leased a former Laundromat on Nostrand Avenue near Fulton Street and began transforming a concrete shell into a cafe. They're hoping it will become a catalyst for a new type of commercial space in an area dominated by 99-cent stores, nail salons and beauty supply chains.
 While the rent is only $1,900 a month, it has not been easy getting the 800-square-foot cafe open, mostly because of a lack of capital. The same could be said of the neighborhood in general. 
 A residential revitalization has been under way for some time in Bed-Stuy, but the commercial market has not kept pace. According to census figures, the number of households in the neighborhood occupied by their owners jumped more than sixfold in the 1990's. The historic brownstones, some now selling for upward of $800,000, have lured the black middle class back to an area once labeled the largest ghetto in the United States.
 Charles Willis, 34, who bought a house early in 2001, is one of the many new homeowners. He said he would never have considered buying in Bed-Stuy if friends had not told him about the great housing stock. He now lives four doors away from his friends on Macon Street near Nostrand Avenue, which also happens to be around the corner from where Mr. Willis's father lived in the 1950's.
 ''Funny how things come around like that,'' said Mr. Willis, who has an M.B.A. from Columbia University and is a portfolio manager for J. P. Morgan Chase. He counts no fewer than six other Columbia Business School graduates who have bought brownstones in Bed-Stuy in the last four years, all based on word of mouth.
 Indeed, the fastest-growing income group in Bed-Stuy is the category of $100,000 or more, according to a study commissioned in 2002 by the Brooklyn Alliance, a not-for-profit economic development affiliate of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. The same study found that more than half of all commercial space along the Fulton corridor consists of hair and nail salons, down-scale apparel shops, fast-food restaurants and variety stores. Currently, there is not a single full-service grocery store in all of Bed-Stuy, which had 120,000 people in 2000.
 ''The residential is hot, but the commercial is not,'' said Mr. Johnson, sitting for an interview in Le Cafe Starving Artiste, still a construction site that he hopes will soon be drawing people like Mr. Willis. 
 Mr. Okafor, who was born in England but is of Nigerian ancestry, like the star basketball player with the same name, said: ''We want this to be a cafe in the truest sense of the word. We want it to be a gathering place, an all-encompassing experience.''
 The partners see considerable opportunity in the neighborhood. ''You have a lot of people who buy their goods and go out in Manhattan; then they get on the train and go home,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''We want to provide those commercial and aesthetic services that we know are in huge demand.''
 To that end, Mr. Johnson organized a meeting of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, a community development corporation, and a group of neighbors who want to open businesses. It turned out that his timing was perfect. 
 ''When Todd Johnson came to us a couple months ago, we were already forming a group to connect local entrepreneurs with local capital,'' said Geri Jasper, vice president for economic development of the Bed-Stuy Restoration Corporation. Ms. Jasper is hoping to have the first formal local investor network meeting in October.
 While the Restoration Corporation works on establishing the network, other Bed-Stuy residents have relied on equity from their brownstones to finance some upscale shops. 
 Monique Greenwood, a longtime community activist and business owner in the neighborhood, bought a brownstone 15 years ago. Using equity from her house, she opened a bed and breakfast on Lewis Avenue and named it the Akwaaba, meaning ''welcome'' in a language spoken in Ghana. She later opened a restaurant by the same name and purchased a third building on Lewis Avenue with five commercial spaces. Ms. Greenwood said all of the locally owned boutique shops in her building are operated by people who used equity from their Bed-Stuy homes.
 A few other locally owned businesses have opened or are set to open soon, including a bakery on Lewis Avenue; a restaurant called Food4Thought on MacDonough Street; Ibo Landing, a home decorating shop on Throop Avenue; and Misu, a clothing store, also on Throop. Most of the new business activity, aside from a recently opened juice bar, Juke Joint Juice Jaffe, is noticeably absent from Fulton Street, despite a four-year community effort known as Fulton First. 
 With a grant from Fleet Bank and financing from the City of New York, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and the Bed-Stuy Restoration Corporation have been managing a $4 million effort to revitalize the commercial corridor along Fulton. Fulton First will experience its first major success when Applebee's breaks ground in September for a 7,500 square-foot restaurant in Restoration Plaza. It will be the first national restaurant chain, aside from fast-food outlets, to open in Bed-Stuy since the 1960's.
 Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, said the initial phase of Fulton First was geared toward cleaning up the street and assisting shop owners with storefront improvements. He readily admits that this does not solve the fundamental problem of achieving a better balance of retail options. ''People will tell you that Fulton used to have everything available,'' Mr. Adams said. ''Now, if you live in central Brooklyn, you have to get in a car to go shopping. It runs counter to a good quality of life in the city.'' 
 Mr. Adams hopes Fulton First will build on Applebee's success. The main obstacle, according to Mr. Adams, is that property owners on Fulton ''just don't get it.'' He added: ''There are a lot of absentee landlords who didn't come to our meetings and didn't get involved. So long as the buildings are performing reasonably well, they leave it alone. When regional retailers start giving the street a second look, landlords will be surprised to get the call. Right now, their phones are not ringing.''

HEADLINE: Who You Gonna Call? Good Luck if It's a Taxi

BYLINE: By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
ON the priority list of transportation options in the state, cabs are at the bottom. There have been long debates over train service and the constant congestion on the highways, but there are few words spoken about cabs. This is, after all, a state where executives don't call a cab, they hire a car. Cabs hardly even get a mention in the Connecticut Transportation Strategy Board's 20-year plan, which addresses every conceivable kind of transportation in the state.
 It's no wonder. Connecticut cities and suburbs depend far less on taxicabs to move people from one place to another than the big cities. In fact, 22 towns don't have service at all. Residents can punch in cab company numbers until their fingers are sore, but a cab will never come in the towns of Bethany, Bethlehem, Brooklyn, Canaan, Colebrook, Cornwall, Eastford, Goshen, Hampton, Litchfield, Lyme, Middlebury, Morris, Norfolk, North Canaan, Prospect, Salisbury, Scotland, Sharon, Warren, Willington and Winchester.
 ''No one ever even asks,'' Evelyn Goodwin, the town clerk of Litchfield, said about cab service. ''That's a thing of the past.'' 
 Even in the cities the service is spotty. Cabs are at the train stations and airports, but stand on a street corner with a raised arm to hail a cab, and all you'll probably get is a few friendly people waving back. And no one expects the cab situation to get any better.
 Oz Griebel, head of the Transportation Strategy Board, said cabs were not a priority.
 ''While cab issues are certainly germane to the transportation issue, they're not a strategic issue,'' he said. ''We've tended to focus more on mass transportation, and many major cities have been promoting train and bus service. People are saying if there are going to be public dollars spent, that's where they should be spent.''
 No one sees that as a problem, but Bruce Schaller, the principal of Schaller Consulting in Brooklyn, N.Y., which specializes in urban transportation issues, said it could become one. For cities like Hartford that are hoping projects like Adriaen's Landing will increase economic activity, cab service becomes an important component, he said.
 ''You want people to be able to walk out of a convention center, a hotel, a stadium and get a cab,'' Mr. Schaller said. ''People get the sense then that this is an urban environment. It's an important supporting service to economic activity, as part of an overall strategy by a city for economic development. There is a real value to that level of service. And many cities want to provide a New York City-like taxi service, but they aren't there yet.
 ''You also want a place to feel like the place that everybody wants to go to,'' he said. ''And there are many signals that you are in such a place, and one of those signals is good cab service.''
 Bradley International Airport has some of the best service, with from 20 to 50 cabs in line waiting for fares, said Brian Baik, the airport's transportation planner. Still, he said, the average wait for a cabby to get a passenger is about three hours. Stamford, New Haven and Bridgeport have taxis lining up at their Metro-North stations, but at other stations along the train route, riders must call and wait for a cab. 
 During the summer in Hartford, cab drivers at the train station said, business is so slow they can wait five hours or more for a fare.
 ''You wait a lot,'' said Franky Matta, a driver who was parked in an orderly line outside the station.
 So with not enough demand to keep the about 900 licensed cab drivers busy, even those in the cities, there is no incentive for drivers to wander around looking for fares. 
 The word has long been out in Willington about the lack of cabs.
 ''Living in a rural area the way we do,'' said Isabel Weigold, the town historian, ''we know we'll have to rely on our devices to get from one place to another.''
 Cheryl Anderson, pastor of the First Congregational Church on the Green in Washington in northwest Connecticut, has yet to use a taxi in Washington.
 ''Living out here, you can't survive without a car,'' she said. ''Obviously, you don't walk out on the street and hail a cab here, although I have seen a cab driving around Washington.'' There is one cab company that serves the town, and it's in Southbury.
 Litchfield had a cab company, which was run by Charles Linsley, a former selectman. Mr. Linsley said he once had a thriving cab business.
 ''The livery business has taken over now,'' he said. ''People here know to call a car service if they need a ride.'' Often, the destination is Manhattan and the fare is $150. 
 Mr. Schaller, the consultant, said that in the suburbs, most taxi service was done through dispatchers.
 ''And even there you have issues arise in areas that generate a low number of calls for service because there won't be a cab in the immediate area,'' he said. ''And people don't want to wait a long time for a cab and drivers don't want to drive a long distance for pickup, especially if the customer may not be there when they get there. That's the challenge both from the industry and government perspective of providing taxi service in low-density areas.''
 Cheshire, a town of 29,000 that had been doing without cab service for many years, managed to attract a cab company in 2003. This was good news for Cheshire Academy, a private sixth through 12th grade boarding and day school whose students previously needed to coordinate rides from faculty members or friends to get to the train station.
 ''The cab company talked to Charlie Mitchell, our dean of student life, about whether kids would be using it,'' said Philip Moore, a spokesman for the school. ''Boarding students aren't allowed to have cars on campus, and I know that kids have used the taxi service during the year.'' 
 There are about 80 cab companies in the state, primarily in the state's urban areas, and mostly in Fairfield County, where Metro-North is heavily used. The drivers said it was difficult to make much money because of the lack of business. Marco Henry, the president of the Taxicab Association of Connecticut, a consortium of cab companies, said drivers made an average $400 a week.
 ''Operating a cab is much more expensive now, with gas prices so high,'' he said. ''But $300 to $500 a week is better than working at McDonald's for $200 a week flipping burgers.''
 Drivers determined to make more than a few dollars often have rejected riders who are not traveling a significant distance. They are waiting for the big-ticket rider, the one going to New York or to a casino.
 ''I picked up one guy at the Milford train station a few years ago,'' said Gordon Hays, a dispatcher with Milford Taxi Cab. ''I drove him to Mohegan Sun, waited four hours and then brought him to Atlantic City. I made about $1,200. That doesn't happen every day, but you can get those kinds of fares.''
 Javier Diez of Stamford, who was waiting for a cab in Stamford recently, said he sometimes had a problem getting a cab.
 ''When I lived closer to the station, the drivers would reject me all the time,'' he said. ''They just didn't want to take me such a short distance.''
 Stamford recently placed a taxi monitor at the station to better organize service there and stop drivers from rejecting passengers, but the service was suspended after complaints about a $2 surcharge to passengers, which paid for the monitor.
 There is no monitor at the Hartford train station. Arthur Duncan stood outside his cab, leaning against a rail that separates the sidewalk from the buses that line up at the station. Customers have become so precious that cabbies sometimes have fought over them, he said. Mr. Duncan, a veteran driver, owns his cab and his company, Arthur's City Cab.
 ''There's not enough business for all these cabs,'' he said. Even the casinos haven't helped much; a bus ride from the Hartford station to Foxwoods costs $21. A cab ride costs $90. 
 Mr. Duncan faulted corporate layoffs in Hartford for the loss of cab business and said he was resting his hopes on the Adriaen's Landing project alongside the Connecticut River, which includes a new convention center. He rejoined his colleagues, who stood at the railing in their shorts and sneakers, waiting for the next customer. It might be a while, he said.
 Most cab drivers work 12-hour days, often splitting a 24-hour cycle with a partner. In Stamford, many of the drivers interviewed said they had grown up in Haiti, a few in Pakistan, others in Bangladesh. Some lease their cabs from their companies, others own them but sign on with the cab company to get licensing, car repair and other benefits. Many of the Stamford Taxi drivers sitting recently at the Stamford station own their cabs and pay several hundred dollars a week to the company for insurance, licensing and dispatching services. 
 New Haven cabbies stay in line most of the time without a monitor, although they periodically fight over fares who fail to take the first cab available. 
 Gregory Leigh has been driving a taxi in New Haven for five years. He leases the cab from Metro Taxi for $700 a week, he said, and makes about $1,000 in fares weekly, for a profit of $300. On a recent Monday morning, he was sitting in his Metro cab, waiting in line for the next available fare.
 ''I like living on the edge,'' he said. ''It's a rough business, but I've had fun. And it runs pretty fair down here. But when it gets slow, everybody gets itchy and frustrated, and I've seen cabbies refuse people who weren't going very far. That's not right; we're in customer service. If you're not committed to that, you really shouldn't be in the business.''
