HEADLINE: Earthquakes' Future Remains in Doubt

BYLINE: By JACK BELL

 BODY:
On Saturday night, the San Jose Earthquakes went retro, wearing the red uniforms of their predecessor in the North American Soccer League, looking back because there may be nothing to look forward to.
 The Anschutz Entertainment Group, which operates the Earthquakes in Northern California (and four other M.L.S. teams, including the MetroStars), is prepared to move the team to San Antonio or to sell it to Club America of Mexico, which would move the team to Houston, if local investors are not found by Sept. 17.
 ''It's obvious to us they don't want the team,'' Colin McCarthy said in a telephone interview, referring to A.E.G. McCarthy is a lawyer, an Earthquakes fan and the president of the grass-roots group Soccer Silicon Valley. At a meeting last week, members of the group extracted a pledge from A.E.G. officials that will give S.S.V. less than a month to find an investor to keep the team in San Jose. 
 Mayor Ed Garza of San Antonio, who was in New York yesterday talking to league officials, is interested in obtaining an expansion franchise for 2006, but he is ready to pluck the Earthquakes for next season. ''This is a market ripe for the taking,'' he told The Houston Chronicle last week.
 M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber said in a telephone interview: ''We hope we can find a way to keep the Quakes in San Jose through the combination of local ownership and a new stadium.''
 Club America, based in Mexico City and owned by the television company Televisa, was stung when Chivas Guadalajara jumped into M.L.S., putting a second team in Los Angeles next season. Club America held negotiations with A.E.G. earlier this year about the Earthquakes.
 ''I'm not opposed to Club America becoming an investor in the Quakes, but what's the rush with selling?'' McCarthy said. ''I'm expecting the worst, but I've already heard from some possible investors, who I can't name.''
 The Earthquakes have won the M.L.S. championship in two of the past three seasons. The club has a long association with the area -- George Best played for the club in the 1980's when it was part of the N.A.S.L., and it was formerly owned by Milan Mandaric, who now runs Portsmouth of the English Premier League. San Jose has one of the best young American players, Landon Donovan, but the team continues to struggle with attendance. On Friday, Soccer Silicon Valley held a rally in downtown San Jose that drew more than 1,000 people. But Saturday's game attracted only slightly more than 10,000.
 The Earthquakes are desperate for a new stadium and have rejected a proposal to renovate Spartan Stadium.
 ''The Earthquakes would like a new publicly funded stadium dedicated to soccer that could cost the taxpayers more than $40 million,'' Mayor Ron Gonzales of San Jose wrote in an opinion article published Sunday in The San Jose Mercury News. ''In this economy, however, with a local law that requires an election for voters to approve public financing for any major sports facility, the whistle has blown the game over before we've started to play.''
 If it moved to Houston, the team could play at Robertson Stadium at the University of Houston, which holds about 30,000. A move to San Antonio could launch Garza's plan to build a soccer stadium for the new team. M.L.S. already has one team in Texas, the Dallas Burn, which will be known as F.C. Dallas 96 beginning next season.
 M.L.S. will expand to 12 teams next season with Chivas USA and another team in Salt Lake City.

MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER
Rapids Protecting Their Home Goal
 The MetroStars were a mile high and a goal short Saturday night in Colorado, a place that has been inhospitable for visiting M.L.S. clubs this season. The Rapids are 5-1-5 at home this season, scoring only nine goals but giving up four.
 Goalkeeper Joe Cannon leads the league with nine shutouts and a .919 goals against average. He has not allowed a goal at home since June 19, a span of 491 minutes. Colorado's Jordan Cila, who is from Jericho, N.Y., scored the game's only goal, his third of the season. All three have been against the MetroStars.

METROSTARS -- The club has lost two straight games by 1-0 scores after having won four of five. The club expects Pablo Brenes back for Sunday's match against second-place Columbus. Brenes played for Costa Rica in the Olympics and had a strong tournament playing on the left side of the midfield. Brenes has played in only six games for the MetroStars, starting once, and will be hard pressed to supplant Eddie Gaven.

LOS ANGELES -- Carlos Ruiz scored in the 89th minute, his 11th goal of the season, as the Galaxy salvaged a 1-1 draw with visiting Chicago in Steve Sampson's debut as coach. Sampson, the former coach of the national teams of the United States and Costa Rica, replaced Sigi Schmid last week.

COLUMBUS -- The Crew is unbeaten in its last nine games but remains in second place behind the MetroStars in the Eastern Conference after a 2-2 draw with D.C. United before a sellout crowd of 23,849 at Crew Stadium. For United, 15-year-old Freddy Adu, now attacking out of the midfield, played the full 90 minutes for a third straight game. The Crew has signed defender Tony Sanneh, who had played in Germany since 1999.

ENGLAND
Arsenal vs. Nottingham Forest
 Rampaging Arsenal can set the English record for most games without a loss (43) against the visiting Blackburn Rovers tomorrow at Highbury. If Arsenal continues its run, it could reach No. 50 against Manchester United on Oct. 24 at Old Trafford and No. 75 against its visiting north London rival, Tottenham, on April 23.
 The Nottingham Forest streak was ended in 1979 by Liverpool. Arsenal started its streak in May 2003 after a loss to Liverpool. Forest won two European Cup titles (beating Malmo of Sweden in 1979 and Hamburg of Germany in 1980), the first at the end of its domestic streak, the second the next season. Arsenal has yet to make a significant impact in European competitions.
 Forest had a 21-0-21 record during its streak; Arsenal is 30-0-12. During it streak, Forest allowed only 22 goals and had 25 shutouts; Arsenal has conceded 31 goals and has had 16 shutouts. Forest scored four or more goals once (4-0 over Manchester United in December 1977), while Arsenal has scored four or more goals nine times. Forest scored 58 goals during its streak, while Arsenal has already scored 93.

HEADLINE: Folly in the West Bank

 BODY:
The Bush administration is driving American credibility as a Middle East peacemaker to a new low with its support for a major expansion of Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank. While designed to provide a short-term boost to Israel's embattled prime minister, Ariel Sharon, this cynical change in administration policy will have important long-term costs. It will further demoralize Israeli and Palestinian moderates, frustrate Washington's closest European and Middle Eastern allies, and undermine the American-backed road map peace plan, which, though a long shot, is the only current peaceful political alternative. 
 Last week Mr. Sharon issued tenders for the first 1,001 of a planned 1,634 heavily subsidized new apartments in existing West Bank settlements. Israel has long contended that expanding existing settlements, which it calls ''natural growth,'' somehow does not violate the road map's call for a freeze on all settlement activity, even though the road map specifically excludes this form of expansion. ''Natural growth'' has accounted for most of the nearly 100,000 additional West Bank settlers since 1992, a near doubling of the settler population there. Most of these, including the latest group, have been attracted by huge government subsidies. Yesterday Israel announced it was rezoning land for a further 533 new settler homes on the outskirts of Jerusalem.
 Settlements are such a sensitive matter because they cut directly to the core of the Israeli-Palestinian issue -- the ultimate division of the land of Palestine. To be just, workable and sustainable, any peace plan will have to divide that land into two coherent territories that are defensible and economically viable. The presence of more than 250,000 Israeli settlers scattered across the occupied West Bank, Gaza Strip and Golan Heights, leaving aside the added complications of East Jerusalem, make that division immeasurably harder. Every new increase, ''natural'' or otherwise, adds to the challenge. No one step by Israel would be likely to do more to restart peace talks and isolate Palestinian terrorists than announcing a genuine freeze on all settlement construction. 
 No recent administration has been less engaged in the pursuit of Middle East peace than the Bush administration. Now it seems to be sliding from dangerous passivity to outright obstruction.

HEADLINE: State Certifies Yonkers Budget (But Not Without a Warning)

BYLINE: By KIRK SEMPLE

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi certified Yonkers's overdue budget on Monday but said the plan still troubled him, and he warned that unless the city devises a blueprint for its long-term financial health it faces a future of budget crises.
 ''The budget has serious problems, specifically a number of one-shot revenues and an optimistic projection,'' Mr. Hevesi said in a written statement issued by his office. ''Most important, there is no long-term plan for how Yonkers will deal with its continuing financial problems.'' 
 Since 1976, the state's comptroller has had to certify Yonkers's budget each year before the city could collect taxes and borrow money. But the tension between the city and Albany became particularly acute this year. The city's council approved a $681.6 million spending plan on Aug. 12, six weeks late and the last among governing authorities in the state with a July 1 budget deadline. The plan was approved only after Mr. Hevesi threatened legal action against the city.
 In a letter sent to Mayor Philip A. Amicone on Monday, Mr. Hevesi outlined six principal concerns with Yonkers's budget, including the city's use of its fund balance to pay for operating expenses and its practice of borrowing to help balance the budget.
 ''The city's decision to borrow for expenses that were previously paid on a pay-as-you-go basis is a troubling indicator of the city's future financial health,'' Mr. Hevesi said in the letter.
 He also suggested that the city's mortgage tax estimate was overly optimistic and criticized the lack of funds to cover either unanticipated emergencies or pay for raises that might result from ongoing contract talks with three unions.
 Finally, Mr. Hevesi urged the city to develop a long-range financial plan that would anticipate a new revenue source for the school system to replace the decline of state desegregation settlement payments, which will end in 2006.
 The school board is facing a $25 million budget shortfall this year, which prompted the laying off of 419 teachers and staff this summer, including most music and art teachers, guidance counselors, psychologists and social workers. The cutbacks also included the elimination of all extracurricular activities and interscholastic sports except for fall varsity sports in the high schools.
 Mr. Amicone has insisted that the state has the obligation to make up the school board's shortfall.
 In Mr. Hevesi's statement, he acknowledged that ''Yonkers officials believe they are not getting their fair share of state support.'' But Mr. Hevesi added that ''constant budget crises are bad for Yonkers schools and bad for its economy and in the long run will cause more damage than any realistic increase in aid would offset.''
 Mr. Amicone and the office of Yonkers Finance Commissioner James LaPerche did not return calls on Monday for comment.

HEADLINE: Why Camping Isn't What It Used to Be

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 David Brooks is right that stratification of society has accounted for the ''professionalization'' of the lives of teenagers. But perhaps this has less to do with pushy parents, as Mr. Brooks suggests, and more to do with the declining state of our economy's job picture.
 Upper-middle-class kids who forgo high school work experience for camp risk being excluded from top colleges, which in turn may deprive them of a shot at one of the shrinking number of high-paying, skilled positions in the United States.
 And many of the ''poorer kids from Brooklyn and the Bronx'' are very likely working summers these days to help their families make ends meet, since more of their parents are unemployed or in minimum-wage jobs that can't sustain families as they once could. 
 Maybe kids could afford just to be kids if they weren't forced to assume adult roles by our gloomy labor situation.

Jonathan A. Pastor
Fort Lee, N.J., Aug. 21, 2004

HEADLINE: In Battle for Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Suburbs Probably Hold the 
Key

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WAYNE, Pa. 

 BODY:
The ladies lunching on the veranda of the venerable Wayne Hotel here had nothing nice to say about Senator John Kerry, but that did not prevent them from saying it. 
 ''He's a fraud,'' said Alida Haslett, 53, who works in a framing shop and lives in nearby Bryn Mawr. ''I don't believe he's a war hero.''
 Her companions were equally sour on Mr. Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee. 
 ''He's a Kennedy wannabe,'' said Carol Ogelsby, 50, who sells real estate.
 ''There's nothing like a wannabe,'' put in Betsy Grace, also 50, who works in architectural restoration.
 Those women are crucial to President Bush's hopes for winning Pennsylvania. They voice no complaints about the economy, see the American presence in Iraq as positive and support the president's opposition to same-sex marriage, although they are mixed on his opposition to abortion rights.
 In short, the women reflect the Republican values that have prevailed for generations along this stretch of long-settled affluent suburbs named for the Main Line of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which began ferrying commuters westward from Philadelphia in the 1880's and where, Ms. Ogelsby said, the median price of a home runs $700,000 to $800,000.
 But Mr. Bush cannot take too much comfort from the women. Even they expressed a sense of foreboding about his chances here in November. Ms. Grace conceded that she was at odds with her own family. 
 ''They're not all Republicans,'' she said. ''In fact, I'm probably one of the few. It's a little scary.'' 
 Ms. Ogelsby said that she had Republican friends ''who are angry at Bush and went to see 'Fahrenheit 9/11,' and they all stood up and clapped at the end.''
 Voters here in Delaware County and in three other suburban counties are overwhelmingly registered Republicans. But three of the counties, Bucks, Delaware and Montgomery, tipped the state for Bill Clinton in 1992 and 1996 and for Al Gore in 2000. 
 This trend in the state's affluent southeastern suburbs is reflected in the state's grittier southwestern counties, where the economy has long been tied to big steel. Since the New Deal and the rise of unions, those counties have been staunchly Democratic. But for nearly two decades, the culturally conservative blue-collar workers in the southwest, where hunting is practically a religion, have been leaning Republican.
 Because the suburban southeast and Philadelphia are bigger than the old mill towns of the southwest and Pittsburgh, the southeast tends to control statewide elections. The state last voted for a Republican for president in 1988, when the suburbs sided with the first George Bush.
 For several weeks, Mr. Kerry has been leading in state polls by five or six percentage points. Depending on the poll, Mr. Bush is losing the suburbs or is only slightly ahead, but not by enough to carry the state, at least now.
 Either way, analysts and both campaigns pinpoint the suburbs as the battleground of this much-tussled-over state, where Mr. Bush has made 32 campaign visits, more than to any other state and a clear sign of the importance of its 21 electoral votes.
 ''If you win the Philly suburbs, you win the state,'' said G. Terry Madonna, a political scientist at Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster. ''The Republicans can't give up that many votes in the suburbs and still make them up somewhere else.''
 Mr. Bush's camp says it can.
 ''You still need to win in the suburbs,'' Leslie Gromis Baker, the Mid-Atlantic regional chairwoman for the Bush campaign, said. ''But you don't need the margin you used to, because you can make it up in the southwest.''
 Ms. Gromis Baker argued that when the economy was good -- or good enough -- Democrats in the southwestern counties outside Pittsburgh would vote Republican because they felt more in tune with Republican values.
 Polls show the economy and the Iraq conflict -- or more broadly terrorism -- vying as the most important issue. Voters disapprove of the job Mr. Bush is doing, saying that it was wrong to go into Iraq and that it is time for a change. 
 Robert Sless, 56, owner of the Station Cafe, tucked into the historic train station here, reflects that reality and, like others here, seemed more anti-Bush than pro-Kerry.
 ''I'm a big Kerry fan,'' Mr. Sless said. Then, he quickly corrected himself. 
 ''Well,'' he added, ''let's put it this way. I'm not necessarily a big Kerry fan, but I'm not a big Bush fan, and I think we need a change in this country.''
 Mr. Sless works two jobs, at the cafe and as a manager in the shoe department at the Nordstrom store in the nearby King of Prussia mall. He sees many people who are, as he put it, ''recessionproof.'' But he said that he felt the economic squeeze and opposed the military action in Iraq.
 ''The No.1 issue for me is that we're spending too much of our tax dollars supporting what's going on in Iraq,'' he said. ''It would be nice if during these past few years of recession we could have been spending it to improve our economy.'' 
 Anger at the war in this region is intense. Gov. Edward G. Rendell, a Democrat, said the southeastern area had been saturated with bad news about Iraq because several people involved in the prisoner-abuse scandal and two people who were beheaded in Iraq were from the Philadelphia news media market. Josh Gansky, 30, a school counselor who was shopping at the farmers' market farther down the Main Line, in Ardmore, said Iraq was central.
 ''Bush went in without a plan,'' Mr. Gansky said. ''He didn't understand the culture and the people who live there, and I think that sums up his attitude toward America. He doesn't understand the culture or the people who live here.''
 In the little borough of Narberth, closer to Philadelphia, several anti-Bush signs have appeared on lawns. One is at the house of Charles Bosk, 56, a professor of sociology and medial ethics at the University of Pennsylvania, who said he was disgusted with Mr. Bush and traced that disgust to the president's inability at a news conference in April to pinpoint any mistakes he might have made.
 ''The absence of thoughtfulness, the absence of going back over the record, the absence of thinking about and having an articulate response to what might have been different, that was a shocking moment,'' said Mr. Bosk, who studies medical errors and patient safety. ''He is guilty of political malpractice.
 ''I've never felt that the country was in such incapable hands.''
 Pennsylvania is a hodgepodge of crosscultural currents and economies. For all the anger toward Mr. Bush in the suburbs, the polls show he continues to command the vast rural counties in the middle of the state. The president also appears to be holding his own in the Democratic but conservative northeast, home of the late Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat whose opposition to abortion alienated him from much of his national party.
 Mr. Bush is running behind, but not by a lot, in parts of the southwest, home to the blue-collar Reagan Democrats as well as Mr. Kerry's wife, Teresa Heinz Kerry, widow of Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania. She maintains a home in Pittsburgh, where the Heinz name and foundations are enormously influential. To emphasize this connection, Mr. Kerry calls their visits there a ''homecoming.''
 The question is whether Mr. Bush can find enough votes in the other areas to compensate for the Philadelphia suburbs. Experts said that depended in part on whether Mr. Kerry could rally voters around his plans for the economy.
 Although the state has lost 157,000 manufacturing jobs since Mr. Bush became president, new jobs are being created, although they do not pay nearly as well as the old jobs. The state unemployment rate of 5.6 percent in July was a shade off the national average of 5.5 percent.
 Voters perceive Mr. Kerry as better able to handle the economy, the polls show, but they also perceive Mr. Bush as a stronger leader and better able to handle terrorism.
 [In a Keystone Poll for Franklin and Marshall College released on Aug. 17, 35 percent of voters strongly agreed with the statement that Mr. Bush ''shows strong leadership qualities,'' with 24 percent saying that about Mr. Kerry. 
 [The president frequently uses visits to the state to emphasize these traits, as he did on Aug. 17 at a Boeing plant here in Delaware County, where he focused on national security. Mr. Bush also received high marks -- 37 percent -- in the poll for saying ''what he believes, not what people want to hear,'' a category where Mr. Kerry had 19 percent.]
 Candor is important to voters like George Howard, 80, a retired printer who was walking his dog past the smokestacks of an old steel mill in Homestead, south of Pittsburgh.
 ''Kerry?'' Mr. Howard asked. ''He's like the wind. He says one thing and then he says something else. I know where Bush stands.''
 Where Mr. Bush stands on the issues is not necessarily where Mr. Howard stands. He said he was unhappy with the economy because his daughter could not find work. And he said he was furious about the war in Iraq. But Mr. Howard owns a gun, loves to hunt and said he was likely to vote for the president. 
 ''If it wasn't for the war, I would definitely vote for Bush,'' he said.
 Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster who has studied Pennsylvania extensively, said many voters saw the economy as the overriding issue and yet were prone to vote more on character than economic policy.
 ''Our job is to change that equation,'' Ms. Lake said. ''They think Bush has a strong, steady character. If social issues trump the economy, the Republicans win.''

HEADLINE: Home Resales Dropped 2.9% Last Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes fell 2.9 percent in July from a record in June, the first drop in seven months, a private report showed yesterday. 
 Resales declined to 6.72 million single-family houses at an annual rate, the third highest on record, after a revised 6.92 million in June and 6.81 million in May, the National Association of Realtors said in Washington. 
 Sales were forecast to fall to a 6.81 million annual rate in July. Estimates ranged from 6.5 million to 7.1 million. 
 The median sale price was $191,300, up 8.7 percent from July of last year. 
 Rising mortgage rates in June, when many contracts for July resales were signed, might have deterred some buyers. The record-setting pace of sales growth set in the first half of 2004 could not be sustained, economists said. 
 ''I've been looking for these numbers to fade for several months now, because they've been so incredibly high,'' said Joel Naroff, chief economist at Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa. ''There's almost no place to go but down.'' 
 Thirty-year mortgage rates averaged 6.29 percent in June, up from 6.27 percent in May and 5.91 percent in April.
 ''The most interesting thing about the July numbers is that they reflect closed properties in June, when interest rates were actually rising,'' said James Gillespie, chief executive of Coldwell Banker Real Estate, a unit of the Cendant Corporation, adding that his company's sales in July rose 11 percent. ''That's a good number any time,'' he said. 
 Home purchases may also have been aided in recent months by concerns among buyers that rates would continue to increase as the Federal Reserve raised borrowing costs to deter inflation, John Ryding, chief United States economist at Bear Stearns, wrote in a note. 
 The Fed's Open Market Committee raised the target rate for overnight loans between banks to 1.25 percent from near a 46-year low of 1 percent on June 30, and again to 1.5 percent on Aug. 10. The committee meets again Sept. 21. 
 Instead of rising with the target rate, mortgage rates have declined. Last week, the typical 30-year rate was 5.81 percent, close to the record low annual average of 5.8 percent set in 1965, according to Freddie Mac, the second-biggest buyer of mortgages.


GRAPHIC: Photo: A house for sale in Homewood, Ala. Rising mortgage rates in June might have deterred some potential buyers in July. (Photo by Gary Tramontina/Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Fischer Loses Latest Appeal On Deportation From Japan

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 24 

 BODY:
Japan ordered Tuesday that Bobby Fischer, the American chess master wanted in the United States for violating a trade embargo, be deported after rejecting his request for protection as a political refugee, his supporters said.
 Mr. Fischer's lawyers immediately filed an appeal with the Justice Ministry, and it was not expected that a final move to deport him would be made soon. 
 The ministry explained its decision to reject Mr. Fischer's bid for political asylum, saying the charges against him in the United States were ''not political in nature,'' according to a statement released by the chess player's supporters, the Committee to Free Bobby Fischer.
 In 1992, Mr. Fischer earned $3.3 million by beating Boris Spassky in a chess rematch in Belgrade of their cold war duel in Iceland. A warrant for his arrest was issued on charges that he violated a trade embargo on the former Yugoslavia.
 The United States ordered the revocation of Mr. Fischer's passport in December, and he was detained on July 13 as he tried to fly from here to Manila. His lawyer said Mr. Fischer, 61, had learned that his passport had been revoked only when he tried to board the flight.
 In the first match against Mr. Spassky, in 1972, Mr. Fischer became a national hero by breaking the Soviet grip on world chess and becoming the first American chess champion in more than a century.
 Last Friday, the Tokyo District Court rejected another attempt to halt the deportation proceedings against Mr. Fischer, who filed an appeal immediately. Mr. Fischer, who is being held at an immigration center in Ushiku, Ibaraki Prefecture, has also tried to fend off deportation by trying to renounce his American citizenship and by marrying a Japanese woman, Miyoko Watai, 59, the acting president of the Japan Chess Association.
 Mr. Fischer, a brilliant but eccentric recluse, has become increasingly vocal in recent years, making a series of anti-Semitic statements on his personal Web site and harshly criticizing the United States, which he said in a radio interview should be ''wiped out.'' His supporters maintain that the charges against him are politically motivated.

HEADLINE: Romance of Tobacco Brought to Life

 BODY:
''Bright Leaves'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 11, 2003; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Sixth Avenue, South Village.
 To describe Ross McElwee's documentary film ''Bright Leaves'' as a study of the tobacco industry in North Carolina, his native state, would be a little like calling a Virginia Woolf novel a manual of etiquette. By the end of this reflective, wise and often hilarious movie, you feel as if he has slapped a huge chunk of raw, palpitating life onto the screen.
 Birth, death, illness, family and social history, childhood and old age, moviemaking, geography and commerce are among the topics Mr. McElwee weaves into a dense but surprisingly orderly bundle of information, memory and conjecture. As a photographer he has a knack for studying a weather-beaten face and instantly discovering the soul inside. Whether he's recording a family gathering, contemplating the beauty of the coastline and his young son frolicking in the surf, or surveying a tobacco field, Mr. McElwee conveys a sensuous appreciation of life. 
 Mr. McElwee, who has made seven feature-length documentaries, is really an American humorist in a tradition that extends from Mark Twain through Garrison Keillor. Narrating the movie in the laid-back drawl of an affable Southern storyteller, he turns personal experience into a speculative personal mythology that is meant to be taken with a big grain of salt.
 This filmmaker is continually connecting the past and present, meditating on what film can and cannot capture of experience, and on the relationship between family history and his own personal changes. Family members and friends appear in vintage clips like vivid flashes of recollection.
 Like an expert yarn-spinner, Mr. McElwee practices a kind of narrative sleight of hand. Although he pretends to be a modest, nearly invisible observer of the life around him, he also plays God by turning his experience of the world into an unfolding home movie. 
 The quest he undertakes in ''Bright Leaves'' is rooted (as his movies often are) in his own family background. His great-grandfather was a tobacco king who created the Bull Durham brand, then lost his fortune to a rival clan, the Dukes, who became North Carolina royalty. Through a cousin who collects vintage films and movie memorabilia, he becomes fixated on a 1950 black-and-white melodrama, ''Bright Leaf,'' about the tobacco wars of the late 19th century, starring Gary Cooper, Lauren Bacall and Patricia Neal.
 McElwee family lore has it that the movie, directed by Michael Curtiz and adapted from a novel by Foster Fitz-Simons, is the story of his great-grandfather. And it prompts Mr. McElwee to embark on an eccentric quest to document the connection. He obsessively reruns the movie and interviews a film scholar along with Ms. Neal and the original novelist's widow.
 But that search is only the spine of a movie that also explores the history and mystique of tobacco, incorporating interviews with smokers of every stripe, from teenagers to dying cancer patients. Mr. McElwee comes from a family of doctors who have treated countless patients for smoking-related illnesses. Some of the film's most sobering moments are Mr. McElwee's uneasy reflections on tobacco as a killer versus its beauty as a plant and its vital role in the economy of North Carolina.
 Because the movie is not a screed against tobacco, some may find it irresponsible for soft pedaling a life-and-death issue. In any case ''Bright Leaves'' leaves you feeling invigorated by the boundless curiosity, humor and high spirits of its creator.

HEADLINE: State Comptroller Will Audit Struggling Westchester Hospital

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
The New York State comptroller's office announced yesterday that it would conduct a thorough audit of Westchester Medical Center, a regional hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., that has been struggling to pull itself out of a financial crisis.
 Last month Westchester County officials asked the comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, to undertake an audit after The Journal News detailed high travel and lodging expenses incurred by a Chicago consulting firm that had been hired to help the hospital right its finances.
 In a letter to the hospital dated Aug. 19 and made public yesterday, the comptroller's office said the audit, which is to begin in September, would include a review of the medical center's financial condition, the use of reserve funds and administrative expenses, in addition to consultant contracts. 
 The hospital has not been directly controlled by the county since 1998. But Westchester still guarantees a large portion of its debt, and county officials have expressed concern that the hospital's ill fiscal health could hurt the county. In recent months, the county has sought more input into the hospital's operations through an oversight committee.
 William J. Ryan, chairman of the county's Board of Legislators, who requested the audit along with County Executive Andrew J. Spano, praised the comptroller's decision. ''I think that it's the appropriate next step,'' Mr. Ryan said. He added that he hoped the audit would cover the past several years, but said he had no reservations about the current management team, Pitts Management Associates of Baton Rouge, La.
 In June, hospital administrators announced another round of layoffs, saying that the cuts would help reduce escalating deficits. The medical center is projecting a deficit of $31.6 million for this year, less than half of the loss posted for last year.
 Gene A. Capello, chairman of the board of the Westchester County Health Care Corporation, which oversees the hospital, questioned the need for an audit, citing the favorable opinion from a reputable outside accounting firm that recently finished an audit. 
 ''It does drain necessary time and manpower from our staff,'' he said, but added that his staff would comply.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Fall for 3rd Day as Fears Ease

BYLINE: By JAD MOUAWAD

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 24 

 BODY:
Oil prices fell for a third day on Tuesday, retreating from the record highs of near $50 a barrel set last week, as exports from Iraq resumed and traders worried less about supply shortages. 
 In New York, light low-sulfur crude for October delivery fell 84 cents, to $45.21 a barrel, on Tuesday. On Friday, the last day for trading September contracts, the price briefly hit $49.40 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange before falling to $48.70.
 Oil prices remain about a third higher than they were in July, run up by a succession of geopolitical threats to supply -- renewed fighting in Iraq, legal squabbling in Russia and political infighting in Venezuela. Most oil-producing countries are pumping all they can, leaving the market little capacity to adjust if a big producer halts exports. 
 Events in Iraq have dominated trading on the oil markets this month. Prices rose when Iraqi exports were halved, then fell this week on reports that exports had resumed in the north of the country and returned to normal in the south.
 ''There's a lot of politics in the price, a lot of expectations of the worst,'' said Mehdi Varzi, senior energy consultant at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in London. ''Perhaps today the market is slightly less concerned about supply disruptions than it was last week. But still, there is concern.''
 Ripple effects from fighting at the shrine of Imam Ali in Najaf, where American forces and the American-backed interim government have been battling supporters of the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr, have been felt far beyond the city. Mr. al-Sadr's loyalists have threatened to attack Iraq's oil facilities. Ever since American troops entered Baghdad in April 2003, opponents of the new government have seen Iraq's oil industry as the country's Achilles' heel. Sabotage attacks in the north of the country kept a pipeline to Turkey, one of Iraq's main export routes, partly shut down for more than a year.
 In the south, in Basra, insurgents set fire Thursday night to the headquarters of the company that operates Iraq's southern oil fields. Fighting forced one of two pipelines in the south to be shut down on Aug. 8.
 Over the weekend, the pipeline to Turkey was reopened and exports flowed from the south at normal levels again. That put Iraq's export levels close to the prewar rate of just over 2 million barrels a day.
 The recent victory by the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chavez, in a recall referendum has eased market worry about that country, but Russia remains a concern. The Kremlin's pursuit of huge tax claims against Yukos, the country's leading oil producer, appeared likely to crimp output. Yukos said on Monday that its 2004 production would probably average 1.72 million barrels a day, 4.5 percent less than it had forecast, though 6 percent more than last year. Export volumes would probably not be affected. 
 So far, there have been few signs that oil prices have hurt the economic recovery in the United States very much. Ben S. Bernanke, a governor of the Federal Reserve, said Monday that he thought $50-a-barrel crude ''won't derail what looks like a self-sustaining expansion at this point.''
 ''The Fed has some scope to respond to the weakening of the economy associated with an oil price increase, so long as we are confident that inflation will remain stable,'' Mr. Bernanke said in an interview on the Public Broadcasting Service. 
 Though Friday's peak price was the highest since the Nymex opened in 1983, oil prices are not extraordinarily high by historic standards. When inflation is taken into account, crude oil would have to rise to about $80 a barrel to match the levels of March 1981.
 Though the unreliability of supply from Iraq has helped push prices up, strong demand has been the main factor in the broader rise in energy prices this year. The International Energy Agency, an adviser to 26 industrialized nations, estimates that global oil demand will reach 82.2 million barrels a day this year, an increase of 3.2 percent, and will rise another 1.8 million barrels a day, or 2.2 percent, in 2005. 
 The boom in China is a primary reason; net Chinese imports of crude oil and refined products like gasoline and jet fuel have doubled in less than two years, the energy agency said. ''The confluence of real and suspected political risk has added a premium on oil prices, while demand from China has surprised everyone,'' said Ian Bremmer, president of the Eurasia Group, a New York consulting firm.
 There is not much that even the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries can do to moderate prices, analysts say. Members of the cartel, which produces a third of the world's crude oil supply, are pumping about 30 million barrels of oil a day, and only one member -- Saudi Arabia, the largest producer in the group -- is thought to have any ability to increase output further.
 The Saudi oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, has said that the country has added one million barrels a day to output in recent months and could pump 1.5 million more a day if needed. But the market has taken little notice of the offer so far, partly because most of the new oil the Saudis could deliver quickly would be undesirably heavy and high in sulfur, and thus difficult to refine. 
 There is no consensus on where prices may be headed. 
 ''The market is concerned about the long-term reliability of supply from Middle Eastern countries,'' Mr. Varzi of Dresdner said. ''The problem is that, fundamentally, $45 a barrel is way beyond what the market can sustain. What goes up must go down.''
 But Bruce Evers, an analyst at Investec in London, said that Iraq's oil infrastructure was still a potential target and was still threatened.
 ''Fifty dollars a barrel isn't a question of if, but when,'' Mr. Evers said. ''There's every chance these pipelines will get blown up again, and prices will spike. We're not out of the woodwork yet, not by far.''

HEADLINE: Bonds's 700th Will Be Pricey, but Not Ruthian

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Imagine this scene: Barry Bonds slams his 700th home run out of SBC Park sometime next month and offers $20 to the fan who wrestles the ball from an armada of angry kayakers before it is waterlogged in McCovey Cove. Bonds would be deemed a miser and the fan would probably sue him for mental cruelty.
 Yet when Babe Ruth hit his 700th, on July 13, 1934, he got away with the $20 swap.
 Ruth hit that homer out of Navin Field in Detroit off Tommy Bridges in the third inning of a 4-2 Yankees victory over the Tigers. According to an article in The New York Times, Ruth shouted, ''I want that ball!'' before he circled the bases. 
 Unidentified ''emissaries'' were then dispatched to hunt for the ball; they returned with Leonard Beals, the youngster who retrieved it. 
 Beals was taken to the Yankees' dugout, where he gave Ruth the ball, and Ruth handed him $20 and a signed ball. In a photograph, both looked mildly satisfied.
 Maybe Ruth knew he had struck a bargain or that no fan could resist his charms and a crisp $20 bill. Ruth had previously established the $20 ceiling as a bounty for his significant home runs; he paid that sum for the balls he hit for his 500th and 600th, The Times reported.
 Adjusted for inflation, Ruth's reward would now amount to $277.
 It's easy now to sneer at Ruth and say: ''Hey, big spender! You made more than the president and you can't give the kid more?'' But this was 70 years ago, in the midst of the Great Depression, before nostalgia turned game-used sports artifacts into memorabilia. And $20 went pretty far back then. Tickets for ''Tobacco Road'' on Broadway cost no more than $2, and a one-bedroom apartment on East 92nd Street in Manhattan rented for only $40 a month.
 By 1961, the price of history began to climb. A restaurant owner paid Sal Durante $5,000 for the ball Roger Maris hit for his 61st home run that season. In late 1998, the first home run hit at Yankee Stadium, by Ruth, on April 18, 1923, was auctioned for $126,500. Two months later, Mark McGwire's 70th home run ball sold for $2.7 million.
 Last year, a court battle between the fans who claimed the legal right to Bonds's 73rd home run ball from the 2001 season led to an auction that yielded $450,000.
 In one of the inequities of a quirky market, Bonds's 70th home run ball from 2001, the homer that tied McGwire's record, was purchased for $52,500 -- yet the one deflected from Cubs outfielder Moises Alou by a fan, Steve Bartman, during Game 6 of last year's National League Championship Series against Florida, was acquired for $113,824 in order to be blown up outside Harry Caray's Restaurant in Chicago.
 Bonds is only 7 home runs from 700, which is a significant marker but not a record breaker. What will Bonds's homer No. 700 be worth, assuming it is auctioned?
 ''I believe it's a six-figure ball,'' said Doug Allen, president of MastroNet, a memorabilia auctioneer.
 Arlan Ettinger, whose Guernsey's auction house sold the McGwire ball, added: ''The 700th won't be his last home run, so one could argue that it would be worth less than the $450,000 for his 73rd. My guess is $200,000 to $250,000.''
 However long Ruth kept the 700th home run ball is unknown. (Ruth's 710th home run ball is in the Baseball Hall of Fame, as are Aaron's 700th and 714th, which tied Ruth's record.) Ruth's daughter, Julia Ruth Stevens, said yesterday that she had no memory of it. 
 ''Oh gosh, we hardly have anything,'' she said from her home in New Hampshire.
 Less than three weeks after Ruth hit the first home run at Yankee Stadium, he donated the bat, which he signed, to The Los Angeles Evening Herald as the grand prize to the winner of a high school hitting contest. The winner died in 1984, and willed the bat to his caretaker. Now, it is to be auctioned in December by Sotheby's and SportsCards Plus, for what they expect to be at least $1 million.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Report Adds Fuel To Welfare Debate

BYLINE: By Leslie Kaufman (NYT); Compiled by George James

 BODY:
Welfare rolls did not rise during the recession of 2001 to 2003, in part because the city stepped up the rejection rate for those seeking aid to 27 percent from 18 percent, according to a report from the Independent Budget Office released yesterday. The report adds fuel to an old debate about the 1995 reform of the city's cash assistance program. Critics have argued that the city is inappropriately blocking individuals seeking aid. But Pat Smith, the first deputy commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, said there were legitimate reasons for the higher rejection rates, including hidden assets ferreted out by computers and better job placement rates for applicants. HEADLINE: Home Price Rises Hard to Track, Fed Chief Says

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers cannot accurately tell whether home values are overheating, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said in a written response released yesterday to a lawmaker's questions about the potential formation of a housing bubble.
 ''House price increases have outstripped gains in income and rents in recent years,'' Mr. 
Greenspan said in a letter to Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, after the Fed chairman testified before the panel on July 20. While that ''raises the possibility that real estate prices, at least in some markets, could be out of alignment with the fundamentals,'' Mr. Greenspan added, ''that conclusion cannot be reached with any confidence.'' 
 ''House prices are difficult to measure given the enormous heterogeneity of the U.S. housing stock,'' Mr. Greenspan said
 He said the global economic recovery ''has become both stronger and more sustainable'' in the last year, even though growth in Asia ''appears to have braked sharply in recent months, as policy measures muffled the boom in the Chinese economy.'' Economic recovery in Latin America and Canada ''appear to be on track.'' 
 In Japan, the country's economy ''may finally be on its way to a self-sustaining recovery,'' Mr. Greenspan said. Growth in Japan and elsewhere in Asia faces ''significant risks'' from ''the possibility of a hard landing in China,'' he said. 
 The Fed chairman also said that the ''case has not been made'' for a need to specifically monitor hedge funds. 
 ''Concerns about market manipulation, whether by hedge funds or others, can best be addressed by enhanced market surveillance,'' Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Conducts Searches In Move to Stop File Sharing
Federal authorities conducted six searches in a move to disrupt a network used to trade copies of movies, software, games and music. The Justice Department said the searches were the first criminal enforcement action related to copyright law aimed at peer-to-peer networks.
 In a peer-to-peer network, like the widely used Kazaa system, the computers of individual users connect to each other to trade files without going through a central computer. The Justice Department has stepped up enforcement of copyright law this year, but until now has focused on the theft of copies of movies and other material to make them available to downloaders. [Page C4.]

Toronto-Dominion Bank in Talks
Shares of Toronto-Dominion Bank traded on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 2.9 percent after the company confirmed that it was negotiating to buy all or part of the Banknorth Group. Shares of Banknorth, which has 350 branches operating under four different brands in Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York and Vermont, increased 10 percent, to $34.88. [C3.]

Sales of New Homes Decline
New home sales slid 6.4 percent in July, to a 1.134 million annual rate, while orders for goods expected to last at least three years gained 1.7 percent. [C4.]

Slump in Oil Prices Continues
Crude oil for October delivery dropped $1.74, or 3.9 percent, to $43.47 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. [C7.]

Equity Firm Buying Dresser-Rand
First Reserve, a private equity buyout firm specializing in energy, said that it would buy Dresser-Rand, a maker of oil and gas refining equipment, for $1.2 billion. [C3.]

Settlement in Janitor Pay Dispute
The Labor Department announced a $1.9 million settlement with Global Building Services, a contractor of the Target Corporation, after finding that Global had not paid overtime to 775 immigrant janitors who often worked seven nights a week cleaning Target stores. [A16.]

European Inquiry Into Acquisition
The European Commission has opened an investigation into the planned acquisition by Microsoft and Time Warner of ContentGuard Holdings, which specializes in software that protects digital material from counterfeiting. [World Business, Section W.]

Harmful to Business Health
Small businesses are coming up with innovative strategies to cope with surging health insurance costs, which many rate as the worst problem they have ever faced. Some are dropping coverage. Others, like Dave Ratner, left, the owner of a retail chain, raised the deductible that his 17 covered employees must pay for hospital stays. Small Business. [C6.]

A Rally on Wall Street as Oil Falls
Stocks rallied as oil prices fell for the fourth consecutive day. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 83.11 points, to close at 10,181.74. The Nasdaq composite index rose 23.83 points, to 1,860.72, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 8.77 points, to 1,104.96. [C7.]

Another Guilty Plea in Enron Case
Mark E. Koenig, the former head of investor relations at Enron, pleaded guilty to one count of aiding and abetting securities fraud. [C7.]

7 Firms to Pay $3.65 Million Fine
Seven brokerage firms have been fined $3.65 million after facing charges that they failed to disclose that they received payments for issuing research on certain companies. [C3.]

A Partisan Twist to Stock Prices
No wonder companies pour money into presidential campaigns. Who wins affects share prices. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. [C2.]

HEADLINE: When a Moving Van Could Spark a Neighborhood War

BYLINE: By PATRICIA COHEN

 BODY:

ARC OF JUSTICE
A Saga of Race, Civil Rights, and Murder in the Jazz Age
By Kevin Boyle
415 Pages. Henry Holt. $26.
 Ossian Sweet was 5 years old when he hid in the Florida bushes as a howling white mob set fire to a black teenager. When he was at Howard University's medical school in 1919, he watched gangs of white veterans rampage through the streets of Washington, D.C., beating and shooting blacks. Once he moved to Detroit to practice medicine, he followed the news of frequent lynchings down South, the riots in Tulsa, Okla., and the burning of Rosewood, Fla. And he listened on a hot summer afternoon in 1925 as a colleague described in terrifying detail how, just hours after he had moved into a white neighborhood, a furious mob had ransacked his home and forced him to turn over the deed.
 But when Dr. Sweet and his wife, Gladys, moved into their new house on an all-white street on Detroit's east side a few weeks later and the rocks started hammering the roof and shattering windows, the story took a different turn. At the evening's end, one white man lay dead and another wounded, shot by one of the panicked black men who had come to help Dr. Sweet protect his Garland Avenue home. Although clearly within the legal definition of self-defense, the Sweets and the nine other men there that night were charged with first-degree murder. 
 The case was a significant moment in the early civil rights movement, spurring the creation of the N.A.A.C.P.'s Legal Defense Fund and spearheading a nationwide assault on residential segregation. Still, it had been largely forgotten, probably because it was covered only sporadically by white newspapers at the time.
 As historians round out the story of America's stumbling march toward civil rights, however, such incidents are being retrieved and examined. HarperCollins released Phyllis Vine's ''One Man's Castle,'' about the Sweet case, this spring, and in July Michigan placed a historical marker at the Garland Avenue house. Now Kevin Boyle, a historian at Ohio State University, has published ''Arc of Justice: A Saga of Race, Civil Rights, and Murder in the Jazz Age,'' his account of the incident and trial.
 ''Arc of Justice'' is an impressive work. Deftly weaving together biography, courtroom drama and social history, Mr. Boyle has produced a meticulously researched and engrossing book. Though the prose overheats at times, Mr. Boyle spins a good tale that holds the reader's attention till the very last line. 
 In a story with no shortage of ready-made villains and heroes, Mr. Boyle resists easy typecasting to draw characters in all their flawed humanity. Ossian Sweet was hailed in the black press as a national symbol of the ''new Negro militancy.'' But pride and the hunger for status had as much to do with his decision to buy the Garland Avenue house as bravery or principle. Dr. Sweet was an insecure striver, a sort of ''ebony Babbitt,'' in Mr. Boyle's phrase, driven by his family and his African Methodist Episcopal faith in self-improvement to break into the ''Talented Tenth,'' the black elite that W.E.B. Du Bois said would lead the race. Meanwhile, Clarence Darrow, who joined the defense team three months after the end of the Scopes trial, was as attracted to the national limelight as to the cause of racial justice; the N.A.A.C.P. was as interested in raising money as in getting not-guilty verdicts. 
 The Sweets' ordeal was a powerful example of the racial prejudice surging through Northern cities in the 20's. The uneven and fragmented treatment of blacks hardened after World War I as nearly a million blacks journeyed north and competition for jobs intensified. The Klan grew explosively. Haphazard separation turned into systematic and codified segregation. Respected blacks who had lived in white neighborhoods for years with no trouble now suddenly faced vicious rejection. As one black newspaper put it, if lynching has been the ''peculiar institution of the South,'' then ''forceful residential segregation'' is fast becoming ''the peculiar institution of the North.''
 The N.A.A.C.P.'s executive secretary, James Weldon Johnson, recognized that housing segregation could energize a coalition of middle-class progressives, white ethnic immigrants and blacks. Blacks might be singled out for exclusion today, he argued, but Jews, Catholics and other immigrants would no doubt be tomorrow. Mr. Johnson turned the Sweet case into a national symbol of the fight against restrictive covenants -- legal prohibitions against selling to blacks -- which the N.A.A.C.P. was also challenging in a case before the Supreme Court (a case it lost that year).
 Racial hate alone doesn't explain the long history of discrimination; it has to be given structure and direction. Mr. Boyle nimbly explains the surrounding forces: the web of banking, insurance and real estate interests behind residential segregation; the shifting economic forces during the country's rapid and ruthless industrialization; and the political crosscurrents in Detroit that created an opening for the Klan as well as for the progressive coalition that, years later, would put Franklin D. Roosevelt in the White House.
 Mr. Boyle also touches on the tangled rivalries within the black community -- from the disdain the elite felt toward less successful brethren to the choice among light-skinned blacks as to whether to pass as white. The aptly named Walter White -- the brilliant blond-hair, blue-eyed dynamo -- could have easily passed but identified himself as a black man and devoted his life to the N.A.A.C.P. Still, he secretly believed ''pure Negroes'' were inferior. As one friend put it: ''There's the conflict -- the nine-tenths white loathing the one-tenth black, one-tenth black hating the nine-tenths white.''
 It took two trials before the fabricated account presented by the police and the block's residents was discredited and the defendants were freed.
 In brief strokes, Mr. Boyle offers revealing insights into the lead players' personalities, writing, for example, that after Darrow finished his emotionally wrenching three-and-a-half-hour closing argument, he ''wiped a tear from his eye, quickly scanned the courtroom to find if his beloved Ruby was in attendance,'' and seeing that his wife was absent, slipped over to an attractive activist to ask if she was ''interested in joining him for a very private lunch.''
 This remarkable tale is filled with rich detail and unexpected twists. The man who sold the Sweets the house on Garland Avenue was actually a light-skinned black passing as white. The prosecutor, Robert Toms, ended up joining the Detroit branch of the N.A.A.C.P. and ultimately presided over the prosecution of Nazi war criminals at Nuremberg. 
 Mr. Boyle takes his title from a quote by the 19th-century abolitionist Theodore Parker: ''The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice.'' 
 The justice, as well as the long slog, can be found both in Ossian Sweet's personal story and in the larger fight against housing segregation. Mr. Sweet won the case, but at great cost, ending his life an unhappy, bitter man. And the Detroit where he lived out his days remains the most segregated city in America.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Rise as New-Home Sales Fall

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
New-home sales showed signs of buckling under the weight of higher interest rates, and orders for durable goods rose more than expected in July, two government reports showed Wednesday. 
 The Commerce Department said new-home sales in July slid 6.4 percent, to a 1.134 million annual rate, their slowest pace since December. Analysts had expected a 1.29 million pace. 
 Orders for durable goods, which are costly manufactured products expected to last at least three years, gained 1.7 percent in July, their biggest monthly increase since March, the department said. Excluding transportation, orders were up a smaller 0.1 percent. June orders were revised up, to a 1.1 percent advance from a previously reported 0.9 percent jump. 
 The July number was well above Wall Street expectations for a 1 percent overall gain, but economists were concerned that most of the rise was in one sector. 
 In a separate report, the Mortgage Bankers Association said new applications for home loans fell last week. The group's market index, a measure of mortgage activity, declined 6.3 percent last week, to 646.3. 
 ''The decline in new home sales is not alarming because it's still above one million units,'' said Ashraf Laidi, chief currency analyst at MG Financial in New York. ''That's still pretty strong. But if we see the fall extend itself, then one could include the housing sector in this soft patch.'' 
 In the durable goods report, overall transportation-related orders rose 5.6 percent, as orders for civilian aircraft more than doubled from June's tally, offsetting declines in demand for autos and military aircraft. 
 ''Aside from the noise that typically comes from aircraft and defense, the report is consistent with an economy still expanding, but at a slower rate,'' said Vincent Boberski, head of fixed income research at RBC Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis. 
 The Boeing Company said in July that it had reached tentative deals with two dozen customers for its planned 7E7 jets. 
 The manufacturing sector has shown signs of regaining steam after being hit hard by the 2001 recession. From January 2001 through July, about 2.7 million factory jobs have been lost. 
 Recently, however, the job picture has stabilized and output, driven by rising worker productivity, has increased. The Federal Reserve said factories ran at their fastest operating rate in more than three years in July. 
 Other sectors besides aircraft also showed strength. Orders for primary metals were up 5.8 percent, and orders for machinery grew 2.1 percent.

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; PREPARING FOR THE CONVENTION: DEMONSTRATIONS; Pg. 7

HEADLINE: Days of Protests, Vigils and Street Theater (Thongs, Too)

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD; Thomas J. Lueck contributed reporting for this article.

 BODY:
They promise to carry a thousand coffins in tribute to fallen soldiers, ''ring out'' the Republicans with chiming bells, bare their anti-Bush thong underwear, don masks to pay tribute to the poor and forgotten, chant, drum, sing and of course, march, march and march, with and without police permission.
 Grass-roots and professional organizers alike, mindful of the 15,000 journalists expected in a town already saturated with the news media, have seized on the Republican National Convention next week as a galvanizing moment raw with emotion around 9/11, the Iraq war and the Bush administration's conduct.
 The largest demonstration, with an estimated 250,000 people expected by organizers for United for Peace and Justice, is an antiwar march Sunday up Seventh Avenue past Madison Square Garden. But many other demonstrations will focus on domestic problems like homelessness and poverty, including an unsanctioned march Monday from the United Nations to the Garden, where the convention will be held Monday through Thursday.
 Some take a humorous or tongue-in-cheek approach, including a ''crossing'' of New York Harbor to ''liberate New York from the Bush loyalists'' and Axis of Eve's plan to expose their politicized underwear Wednesday night in Battery Park. Ring Out the Republicans plans to surround ground zero Saturday night and deliver a cacophony of bells. 
 Al Franken, the comedian and radio host, has asked everybody to open their windows Thursday evening as Mr. Bush takes the stage for his nomination acceptance speech and collectively shout something anti-Bush in an outcry reminiscent of the movie ''Network.''
 ''We will be yelling 'Fuhgeddaboudit!''' Mr. Franken said.
 Other demonstrations are more serious and somber, including a vigil featuring a stone memorial in honor of the victims of terrorism. The Christian Defense Coalition, which has held events against abortion and in favor of the public display of the Ten Commandments, plans prayer vigils outside the Garden on Friday and Sunday. An ad-hoc group of artists, actors and others plan to read the names of dead Iraqi civilians every night next week at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery.
 The terrorist attacks and the Iraq war -- and a general hostility toward the Republican presence in New York -- form the leitmotif of many demonstrations, including a vigil in Central Park on Saturday by the American Friends Services Committee during which the names of American and Iraqis killed in the war will be read and combat boots displayed.
 In a Brooklyn apartment, Michael de Seve, a film director, and companions have been folding cardboard coffins, with the goal of bringing 1,000 to the large antiwar rally Sunday, as a tribute to soldiers killed and a protest against the Bush administration policy of not allowing photographs of coffins arriving from Iraq.
 ''A lot of New Yorkers are furious at the public relations move of the Republicans coming to a town that I don't think could be a less welcoming place on Earth toward their policies,'' he said.
 There are several traditional mass rallies, at least one every day of the convention. They include the ''Still We Rise'' march Monday highlighting AIDS, housing and welfare; an abortion rights rally Tuesday in Union Square; the National Organization for Women gathering in Central Park and a rally by a coalition of labor groups, both on Wednesday. 
 Artists and Activists United for Peace plans a march and rally in Harlem against the Iraq war and violence in American cities during the day on Thursday, when Mr. Bush accepts the nomination. That night, Answer, an antiwar and antiracism group, plans a rally in the designated protest space near the Garden. A police spokesman, Paul J. Browne, said that the police are girding for spontaneous demonstrations that day, too.
 Police commanders said they could not recall a time when the city has experienced such a succession of demonstrations and rallies. The city has issued permits for 29 rallies to have amplified sound equipment or block streets. They range in size from about 40 people, for a prayer vigil outside the Garden, to 250,000, for Sunday's antiwar march.
 ''There is nothing in recent memory of so many protests on such a compressed schedule,'' Mr. Browne said. He said department officials do not keep official records but believe the largest demonstration in the city ever was an antinuclear march in Central Park in 1982 that drew more than 500,000 by police estimates.
 Experts on social movements said New York was bound to be a focal point for venting of all kinds.
 ''I would think New York enhances the climate for protest activity, because it has always been a city that attracted a diverse viewpoint and perspective on the world,'' said Craig Rimmerman, a political science professor at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y. ''The fact that the Republicans chose New York City in light of what happened on Sept. 11 heightens the politics of it all even more.''
 Some protesters could not wait until the official start of the convention, seeking to draw attention to their cause before all the jockeying next week. The Poor People's Economic Human Rights Campaign has set up a makeshift encampment in Brooklyn as a protest against homelessness before their march -- without police permission -- on Monday from the United Nations to the Garden.
 Another group, DNC2RNC, has just completed a march from the Democratic National Convention in Boston to New York, where they plan a street theater performance today on foot down Broadway from Columbus Circle to Union Square.
 Simon Sanchez, an organizer of the march of about 100 people, said, ''We are not only addressing the occupation of Iraq and Afghanistan but of the global South in its entirety,'' referring to the third world.
 At a workshop in borrowed space on Houston Street, young people with the environmental group Time's Up! have been assembling and fixing bicycles to be used in a number of demonstrations, including a ''Critical Mass'' ride Friday evening through Manhattan to draw attention to environmental concerns. 
 That ride, and others that could involve large groups of bicyclists, drew a terse warning yesterday from senior police officials, who said in a news release that they would be ''stepping up enforcement actions against bicyclists who block traffic, ignore traffic signals and otherwise violate traffic laws.''
 Brandon Neubauer, a Time's Up! organizer, said the police warning appeared to signal a different tactic than in the past, when the police used scooter patrols to work with and accommodate Critical Mass rides through Manhattan involving up to 1,500 bicyclists. He said the ride on Friday could draw 2,000 riders, and large groups are expected at bicycle events on Sunday and Tuesday. If the police insist on stringent enforcement of traffic laws, ''it will be difficult and could blow up in their faces,'' Mr. Neubauer said.
 He said he expected the riders to stretch for 20 blocks or more, and engage in ''corking,'' a practice in which some riders block auto traffic at intersections to enable the mass of fellow riders to keep moving unimpeded through red lights.
 Next Tuesday, Time's Up! plans to participate in unspecified ''actions'' as part of a day of civil disobedience called for by anarchists and other groups, Mr. Neubauer said.
 Protest organizers revel at the potential bonanza of attention, but given all the events, many may not get much attention.
 ''It would be a crime if we did not take advantage of thousands of reporters being in town to talk about issues pertaining to family,'' said Cheri Honkala, national coordinator for the Poor People's Campaign.

HEADLINE: A Boom Along the Border

BYLINE: By ELISABETH MALKIN

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico 

 BODY:
Yoshiro Takemoto walks swiftly through the Panasonic factory, showing off the improvements being made to produce the latest generation of flat-panel digital televisions.
 New automated equipment for wiring electronic circuit boards hums away. Japanese-style work teams collaborate to assemble plasma screens. Mr. Takemoto, the president of Panasonic's North American television manufacturing operations, tracks all his components on intricate charts covering the walls of a conference room.
 After a three-year slump, the plant is hiring again. Retooled at a cost of $10 million, the factory created 400 jobs this year to prepare for Christmas sales. 
 Across Tijuana's vast industrial parks, the export assembly plants known as maquiladoras are thriving, posting giant ''help wanted'' signs. In June, an industry group estimated that the Tijuana plants needed to fill some 15,000 jobs. The government announced recently that it expected $300 million of investments in Tijuana this year that would mean another 15,000 jobs; the boom is being repeated all along the border. 
 It is a sharp change. Three years ago, as American consumer demand shriveled and plants shut or moved to China, maquiladoras lost 280,000 jobs. In Tijuana, more than 60,000 factory jobs evaporated. But this year the tide is turning. Maquiladora exports rose 22.4 percent in June, driving a more general export surge for Mexico. The nation expects economic growth of 4 percent this year, the strongest since 2000.
 ''We have lived through the hard times,'' said Cesar Lopez Ramos, the president of the Tijuana maquiladora association. ''We have made it, so we are less vulnerable.''
 Investment poured into Mexico after the North American Free Trade Agreement took hold in 1994. Companies came to take advantage of cheap labor and duty-free access to the United States. But by 2001, the maquiladora industry was shocked to discover how vulnerable it was to the swings of the American economy and to Asian competition.
 ''The business cycle in the maquila sector is a highly exaggerated version of the U.S. business cycle,'' said Gordon Hanson, a professor of economics at the University of California, San Diego. ''Growth in the maquila sector is a couple of times what it is in U.S. manufacturing.'' 
 But analysts say that is not the only factor in the maquiladora recovery. Stung by Chinese gains, many executives have decided that Mexico must sell efficiency, flexible engineering and quick turnaround time, not just cheap labor. 
 ''Those who stayed have had to restructure to diminish costs and raise competitiveness,'' said Jorge Carrillo, a researcher at the College of the Northern Border in Tijuana.
 ''They had to reduce the work force and do more with less,'' Mr. Carrillo said. ''Factors like technology; innovation and delivery are all critical. Now the ones who stayed are starting to grow.'' 
 The shift is clear at the Panasonic plant, where the move to digital television sets with large flat-panel display screens is driving the recovery. 
 Mr. Takemoto has been on the job for three months with one task from Panasonic's parent company, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. ''I was assigned to make this factory able to manufacture flat-panel digital TV's that are competitive globally,'' he said. He summed up his goal simply: ''We will win against China.'' 
 The new sets are revitalizing Tijuana's industry, which has been shipping televisions to the United States since Sony, Sanyo and Panasonic established assembly plants in the 1980's. Samsung followed in 1995. 
 The Mexican government has also helped the maquiladoras by cutting duties on imported Asian components, ending the uncertainty that threatened to drive away many electronics companies. And the state government of Baja California is offering tax breaks. 
 ''Where delivery, proximity and ease of control are important, then Mexico has a fighting chance,'' said Richard Caldwell, president of the Western Maquiladora Trade Association in San Diego.
 Still, Tijuana's recovery is a work in progress, and analysts say the city will take years to get back all the lost jobs. Industries that rely on cheap labor, like garment-making, toy production and furniture assembly, will not return. 
 ''It would be unreal to believe that we will recover all the lost jobs in one year,'' said Juan Morales, who tracks wages and hiring in the city. ''There won't be a double-digit increase.''
 Nevertheless, at some factories the pace is stunning. Saul Garcia Huerta, president of the Mexican division of Kyocera International, held up a cellphone that his year-old Tijuana factory makes for Verizon.
 ''Efficiency in Mexico is higher than in China,'' he said. ''If you assemble this telephone automatically, then the cost of labor stops being important.'' 
 Labor accounts for 7 percent to 10 percent of the phone's cost, he said. 
 Kyocera has hired 1,575 people since April 2003 as it opened its cellphone plant and demand recovered at another plant where it makes ceramic components for electronics. Some 40 percent of the 1,100 workers in the cellphone factory have some technical training, higher than the 20 percent typical in maquiladoras. By October, Mr. Garcia hopes to produce a million phones a month, up from about 600,000.
 Tijuana and other border cities have another advantage. Some of the big items that are manufactured in their new plants -- refrigerators and water heaters, for example -- cost more to ship from Asia. And to avoid holding expensive inventory, American retailers like Home Depot demand that factories supply them continuously, which is easier to do by land. 
 The business in bulky items is a boon to Corrugados de Baja California, a packaging supplier. ''We have the crystal ball,'' said David Ortiz, the company's vice president for sales and marketing. ''If a box plant is slow, then it's not a good sign.'' But his company's sales have risen 30 percent this year.
 The company, a unit of the California-based Orange County Container Corporation, has increased its work force by 40 percent in the last year. The factory has had to raise salaries as much as 40 percent to keep some of the skilled workers it employs to design new packages and make dies for the factory's automated cutting machines. 
 Another niche for Tijuana is in producing medical supplies, which need tight quality control. 
 Tyco's health care division operates a Tijuana maquiladora that makes medical devices like catheters, trays and suction tubing for operating rooms. The plant is regulated and inspected by the United States Food and Drug Administration, and the factory must be able to trace every item in case of a malfunction; because of distance, that is much harder to do for devices made in Asia.
 The Tijuana plant's proximity also helps it work with Tyco's operations in the United States to develop new products, said Victor Montoya, the plant manager. ''It is a lot easier to come to Tijuana versus going to China.''
 Tyco is shutting a plant in Argyle, N.Y., near Albany, and moving some of the work and 300 jobs to Tijuana as the factory handles more automated production. 
 Tijuana's surge is paying off for skilled workers. Factories need to hire more people to operate and repair equipment or design modifications for custom-made orders.
 On a break outside a Tyco electronics plant, Gabriel Diaz discussed his job enthusiastically. Mr. Diaz, 25, a production line leader who started as a maintenance technician six years ago and now makes $130 a week, about five times Mexico's minimum wage, said: ''This is more like a factory. I'm making a career here. I can become a planner or a components buyer.''
 His pregnant wife works in the factory's mail room, and the couple are saving to buy a house. In Tijuana, new developments built for workers like Mr. Diaz offer a two-bedroom house for $25,000, with financing from a government-subsidized mortgage. 
 Not everyone shares his optimism -- especially not lower-skilled workers, many of them single mothers, who take home as little as $60 a week. Carmen Valadez, a longtime labor activist, cites the example of a 34-year-old woman who lost an eye in an industrial accident and struggles to support her three children by working in a maquiladora. ''Her quality of life is low,'' Ms. Valadez said. ''She has no hope. Working full time, you would expect her to be able to get ahead.''
 Still, the steady wages and benefits make maquiladoras a better option than most local employers. 
 On a recent Tuesday, Mayra Amparo Garcia, 37, and Laura Patricia Torres, 20, began at 6 a.m. making the rounds of Tijuana's industrial parks, filling out applications at each plant.
 ''More factories have been opening,'' said Ms. Garcia, whose last job paid $7.35 an hour at a sprinkler factory. ''There is a lot of work,'' she continued. ''I will work wherever there is a job.''
